Date:  Thu, 01 Jan 2015 12:49:43 +0100
From:  Erik Bryssinck 
Subject:  image comet C/2014 Q2 (LOVEJOY) 31 dec.2014
with disturbing moonlight, high humidity and low altitude (16 degrees) from my backyard observatory.

http://www.astronomie.be/erik.bryssinck/c2014q2_20141231.html

Erik Bryssinck

Gianluca

Date:  Fri, 02 Jan 2015 13:03:22 +0100
From:  "José J. Chambó" 
Subject:  Image C/2014 Q2 (Lovejoy)
Comet C/2014 Q2 (Lovejoy) on December 29, 2014 while passing near globular cluster M 79 into Lepus. The comet has increased its brightness until 5th magnitude meanwhile its gassy coma has extended until a diameter of 0.5 degrees (same apparent size as the Moon), the galaxy NGC 1886 is immersed up in the outside of coma. The ionic tail of the comet departs toward northeast getting out the image with a longitude higher than 2 degrees, and showing a rich structure in which highlights a disconnection to half degree from nucleus.
Takahashi FSQ-106ED refractor + SBIG STL-1100M camera (L:1×180 Bin1 + RGB:1x60 Bin2)
Remotely from Siding Spring, Australia
http://cometografia.es/cola-estructurada-lovejoy/

Regards.
José J. Chambó (Valencia, Spain)blog: cometografia.es twitter: @PepeChambo 

Date:  Fri, 02 Jan 2015 13:12:28 +0100
From:  Adriano 
Subject:  RE: [Comet-Images] Image C/2014 Q2 (Lovejoy)
Very very beautiful.
Regards
Adriano Valvasori

To: comet-images@yahoogroups.com
From: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 2 Jan 2015 13:03:22 +0100
Subject: [Comet-Images] Image C/2014 Q2 (Lovejoy)

Comet C/2014 Q2 (Lovejoy) on December 29, 2014 while passing near globular cluster M 79 into Lepus. The comet has increased its brightness until 5th magnitude meanwhile its gassy coma has extended until a diameter of 0.5 degrees (same apparent size as the Moon), the galaxy NGC 1886 is immersed up in the outside of coma. The ionic tail of the comet departs toward northeast getting out the image with a longitude higher than 2 degrees, and showing a rich structure in which highlights a disconnection to half degree from nucleus.
Takahashi FSQ-106ED refractor + SBIG STL-1100M camera (L:1×180 Bin1 + RGB:1x60 Bin2)
Remotely from Siding Spring, Australia
http://cometografia.es/cola-estructurada-lovejoy/

Regards.
José J. Chambó (Valencia, Spain)blog: cometografia.es twitter: @PepeChambo

Date:  Fri, 02 Jan 2015 13:41:32 -0700
From:  Alan Hale 
Subject:  comet book
Hello everyone,

For the past 13 months I have been busily writing a book about my comet
observing. While it started off as a bit of therapy for some difficult times
I was having, in the months since then it has taken on a life of its own. I
have just recently completed the manuscript  my goal was to have it
finished by the end of 2014, and, sure enough, I finished it shortly after
2:00 P.M. local time New Year's Eve.

In a nutshell, this book is my life's story, as told via the comets I have
observed throughout that life. It is not meant to be a book about comet
science, although I do discuss scientific findings when appropriate. Nor is
is meant to be a book about the "how-to"s of comet observing  there are
plenty of those out there. Instead, this is something much more personal,
although I do describe in a fair amount of detail many of the observations I
have made of the various comets, as well as discussing the various things
going on in my life during the times in question. Think of this, perhaps, as
a "comet memoirs."

It would be overly long, and, frankly, boring, if I described every comet I
have observed. (Face it, many of the comets we discuss here, and observe,
are of interest only to die-hard comet astronomers and enthusiasts like
ourselves.) Instead, what I have done is pick out the top 10% of the comets
I have observed, and have discussed those in a fair amount of detail. As for
my definition of "top 10%," that includes, of course, the brightest comets I
have seen, along with those comets that are highly interesting
scientifically, as well as a handful of comets that are of personal interest
to me, either because of some unique observations I made of them and/or some
special things going on in my life at the time. Along the way I do manage to
find ways to discuss many of the other comets I have observed.

While the manuscript is finished, there is still a lot of work left to do.
Proofreading, revisions, updating, etc . . . Plus, one of the primary
reasons why I am writing all of you now: although I attempted, whenever
possible, to use either public domain images, or photos/images I have taken,
there are obviously quite a few comets for which I wasn't able to do that.
Many of you have taken some very good images of the various comets over the
years, and there are some of these I would like to use. At some point in the
not-too-distant future I will be contacting you individually and asking for
permission to use them (and for whatever you might want in exchange).

My goal is to have the book ready to "hit the streets" on the 20th
anniversary of the Hale-Bopp discovery, i.e., July 23, 2015. I am planning
to release the book electronically as an e-book, although I might consider
some printed venues if that becomes feasible. I also intend to issue updated
versions at approximately two-year intervals for as long as I remain active
in comet observing.

For the record, as of the end of 2014 I have made 6297 visual observations
of 412 distinct comets at 562 separate apparitions, dating back to early
1970.

Sincerely,
Alan
> 

Date:  Fri, 02 Jan 2015 14:48:59 -0600
From:  Bob King 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] comet book
Alan,
This is a wonderful idea. So glad you decided to write such a book. I know
I'll want to buy a copy. Great news to start the new year!
Bob

Oggetto: [Comet-Images] comet book

Hello everyone,

For the past 13 months I have been busily writing a book about my comet
observing. While it started off as a bit of therapy for some difficult times
I was having, in the months since then it has taken on a life of its own. I
have just recently completed the manuscript  my goal was to have it
finished by the end of 2014, and, sure enough, I finished it shortly after
2:00 P.M. local time New Year's Eve.

In a nutshell, this book is my life's story, as told via the comets I have
observed throughout that life. It is not meant to be a book about comet
science, although I do discuss scientific findings when appropriate. Nor is
is meant to be a book about the "how-to"s of comet observing  there are
plenty of those out there. Instead, this is something much more personal,
although I do describe in a fair amount of detail many of the observations I
have made of the various comets, as well as discussing th e various things
going on in my life during the times in question. Think of this, perhaps, as
a "comet memoirs."

It would be overly long, and, frankly, boring, if I described every comet I
have observed. (Face it, many of the comets we discuss here, and observe,
are of interest only to die-hard comet astronomers and enthusiasts like
ourselves.) Instead, what I have done is pick out the top 10% of the comets
I have observed, and have discussed those in a fair amount of detail. As for
my definition of "top 10%," that includes, of course, the brightest comets I
have seen, along with those comets that are highly interesting
scientifically, as well as a handful of comets that are of personal interest
to me, either because of some unique observations I made of them and/or some
special things going on in my life at the time. Along the way I do manage to
find ways to discuss many of the other comets I have observed.

While the manuscript is fi nished, there is still a lot of work left to do.
Proofreading, revisions, updating, etc . . . Plus, one of the primary
reasons why I am writing all of you now: although I attempted, whenever
possible, to use either public domain images, or photos/images I have taken,
there are obviously quite a few comets for which I wasn't able to do that.
Many of you have taken some very good images of the various comets over the

not-too-distant future I will be contacting you individually and asking for
permission to use them (and for whatever you might want in exchange).

anniversary of the Hale-Bopp discovery, i.e., July 23, 2015. I am planning
to release the book electronically as an e-book, although I might consider
some printed venues if that becomes feasible. I also intend to issue updated
versions at approximately two-y ear intervals for as long as I remain active
in comet observing.

For the record, as of the end of 2014 I have made 6297 visual observations
of 412 distinct comets at 562 separate apparitions, dating back to early
1970.

Sincerely,

Alan

http://www.virtualtelescope.eu/2015/01/05/comet-c2014-q2-lovejoy-image-05-jan-2014/

Best
Gianluca 

Date:  Mon, 05 Jan 2015 21:04:39 +0000
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet Lovejoy - Dec 24th
Hi all,
Here is a belated image of C/2014 Q2 from Dec 24th. Conditions were not great with very high humidity/haze.
http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2014_q2_2014_12_24dp.jpg
FSQ106 with STL-11k. LRGB image.
Damian

From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Cold pre moonrise Comet Lovejoy
Our first chance at getting comet Lovejoy from cloudy and rainy Arkansas.
http://www.arksky.org/smf/index.php/topic,2440.msg11233.html#msg11233

Very turbulent evening transition but very dark mag. 6.0 skies.

Here is
mono shot of Lovejoy from Dec 31st.
http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2014_q2_2014_12_31dp.jpg
20"CDK
with FLI camera. Unfiltered image.
Best
Wishes
Damian

Date:  Thu, 08 Jan 2015 21:01:28 -0600
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  24 hour morphological changes in 2014Q2
I have just posted a one-on-one comparison with equal sky conditions of comet Lovejoy
(c2014 Q2) from Jan. 8 and Jan. 9 UT.
http://www.arksky.org/smf/index.php/topic,2440.msg11233.html#msg11233

The Jan. 9 image is 480 sec. compared to 300 sec for Jan. 8, mainly in an attempt to
discern if a lot of the skewed filamentary structure of the tail has subsided in the
24-hour period.
Indeed, looking at the Jan. 9 image, the tail has become more narrow near the coma,
with far fewer linear striations near the perimeter of the coma; the skewing and
curving morphology of the tail also appears to be perhaps subsiding with a more
linear structure for the tail now appearing.

Comet was naked eye and estimated at mag. 4.9 to 5.0 in 10 x 50 binoculars.

------------
Clay

Arkansas Sky Observatories
http://www.arksky.org/
ASO Petit Jean Mountain /MPC H41
ASO Petit Jean Mountain South /MPC H45
ASO West Conway /MPC H43
.......serving astronomy since 1971
____________________ 

Date:  Thu, 08 Jan 2015 21:10:11 -0800

Subject:  C/2014 Q2 Lovejoy January 1.3, 2015 in Atacama
Hi members,

Here is the comet near Rigel, Messier 42, and Witch Head Nebula.

C/2014 Q2 Lovejoy with Aposonnar 135mmF2 January 1, 2015 https://www.flickr.com/photos/hiroc/16209601946/

https://www.flickr.com/photos/hiroc/16209601946/

C/2014 Q2 Lovejoy with Aposonnar 135mmF2 Janua... https://www.flickr.com/photos/hiroc/16209601946/ This is a preliminary version only with longer exposure. Lighter parts are saturated. North is up. equipment: Zeiss Aposonnar 135mmF2 and Canon EOS...

View on www.flickr.com https://www.flickr.com/photos/hiroc/16209601946/
Preview by Yahoo

Thank you for looking.

Hisayoshi Kato 

Date:  Fri, 09 Jan 2015 16:26:23 +1030
From:  Ian Musgrave &Peta O'Donohue 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 24 hour morphological changes in 2014Q2
G'Day All

This is exceelent. The tail is very active, indeed there is
substantial variation in tail structure over a perios of a few hours.
It is well worth imaging  repeatedly during the night to capture this
movement.

Cheers! Ian

Ian Musgrave Peta O'Donohue, Jack Francis, Michael James and
Andrew Thomas Musgrave

I have just posted a one-on-one comparison with equal sky conditions
of comet Lovejoy
(c2014 Q2) from Jan. 8 and Jan. 9 UT.
http://www.arksky.org/smf/index.php/topic,2440.msg11233.html#msg11233

The Jan. 9 image is 480 sec. compared to 300 sec for Jan. 8, mainly
in an attempt to
discern if a lot of the skewed filamentary structure of the tail has
subsided in the
24-hour period.
Indeed, looking at the Jan. 9 image, the tail has become more narrow
near the coma,
with far fewer linear striations near the perimeter of the coma; the
skewing and
curving morphology of the tail also appears to be perhaps subsiding
with a more
linear structure for the tail now appearing.

Comet was naked eye and estimated at mag. 4.9 to 5.0 in 10 x 50
binoculars.

Date:  Fri, 09 Jan 2015 13:29:42 -0600
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] disconnection of the tail, comet C/2014 Q2 Lovejoy 08/01/2015
Very interesting; that means that a almost 7 hours transpired from your excellent
high resolution image to the one that I acquired at 02:35 UT on that same evening.
http://www.arksky.org/smf/index.php/topic,2440.msg11233.html#msg11233
The "plasma bubble" that you clearly show quite close to the comet's coma has
drifted greatly in the PA of the ion tail to the northeast of the disconnect event.
In my low res and slightly wider field of view, you can see the "bubble" right at the
lower right corner of the image, in PA 63 degrees, with center some 65.03' distant
from the center of the comet.
Since the bubble is drifting/being ejected along the linear expanse of the ion tail
and still centered on that tail its motion is consistent with the comet itself and
its expulsion velocity can be roughly computed.

Clay
_____
P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
MPC H45 - Petit Jean Mountain South
MPC H41 - Petit Jean Mountain
MPC H43 - Conway West
http://www.arksky.org/

Date:  Fri, 09 Jan 2015 20:44:48 -0600
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Lovejoy on Jan 10 _tail continues change
Tail of c2014 Q2 Lovejoy continues to become more delineated, yet still with
striations and separation obvious; also conspicuous tonight is the brightening of the
dust tail/scatter to the NE of the comet's coma, close to PA 150-160 deg.
http://www.arksky.org/smf/index.php/topic,2440.msg11233.html#msg11233
This three-photo assembly for the last three evenings shows dramatic changes in the
comet's tail structure.

------------
Clay

Arkansas Sky Observatories
http://www.arksky.org/
ASO Petit Jean Mountain /MPC H41
ASO Petit Jean Mountain South /MPC H45
ASO West Conway /MPC H43
.......serving astronomy since 1971

> http://www.astrobin.com/full/147107/0/

> mosaic of the comet did last night, 10 minutes before the day before. Difficult to
> center the blob, but I measured that is situated about 155 'from the false nucleus
>
> regards
> Rolando Ligustri
> ===============================
> C.A.R.A. http://cara.uai.it
> CAST: Circolo AStrofili Talmassons
> www.castfvg.it/fotoccd.htm#comete

http://spaceweathergallery.com/full_image.php?image_name=Michael-JAcger-2014q2201450110blueweb2_1420929787.jpg http://spaceweathergallery.com/full_image.php?image_name=Michael-JAcger-2014q2201450110blueweb2_1420929787.jpg 

Date:  Sat, 10 Jan 2015 18:26:26 -0800
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Comet Lovejoy Q2 in the Starfields of Orion - Jan 7
Greetings Comet friends,

Ive been working hard on this one this evening, and hope youll like it. I wanted to do something really extraordinary with this comet when it was in exactly the right spot to form a good composition with Orion. I used a DSLR on this one, which is not near the quality I would get with a CCD, but it still came out fairly well. Let me know what you think.

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/lovejoyQ2010715-2.html

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com 

Date:  Sun, 11 Jan 2015 03:40:26 +0100

Luc

Rolando, what I see besides the awesome tail detail is what appears to be an anti tail forming under the head. I will have to see if plane crossing is nearing.

Date:  Sun, 11 Jan 2015 11:01:19 -0800
From:  mfortsm@aol.com
Subject:  C/2014 Q2 - 01/09/2015
Two images the first a 1x240 sec exp. Flat&dark applied and no other post exposure processing. The second is a 1x60sec exp also with flat&dark with no other post exposure processing. TV127is - STF8300 camera - Losmandy Titan 5 mount. Bad seeing with winter storm moving in and windy. Thank you

http://www.fototime.com/EA112D2AC5E3CF3/orig.jpg http://www.fototime.com/EA112D2AC5E3CF3/orig.jpg

Date:  Sun, 11 Jan 2015 21:15:34 +0000
From:  David Strange 
Subject:  2014Q2 Animation
2014Q2 Lovejoy taken last night with C8 Hyperstar 4x60sec:

https://www.dropbox.com/s/3v7kjm6v5iwnxeh/2014Q2_20150110_dgs.jpg?dl=0

Animation from last night. 15 x 5min exp. from 20:40h-22:20h (with a
few gaps due to clouds) was aligned by using IMGALT and assembled
using JASC Animation Shop.

http://www.davidstrange.org.uk/Animation...0150110_dgs.gif

David 

Date:  Sun, 11 Jan 2015 14:02:05 -0800

Subject:  Comet Lovejoy and Extensive Nebulosity in Orion - Jan 11
Taken from New Mexico Skies using an FSQ 106 and STL11K camera.
This 30-min single shot shows the comet passing infront of extensive nebulosity in Orion

Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Comet Lovejoy and Extensive Nebulosity in Orion - Jan 11
Thanks, Chris.
The image is just a single-shot 30-min exposure with no fancy processing.
The trail of the comet motion is hidden by the widefield scaling.
Best wishes
Joe

From: Chris Schur comets133@yahoo.com [Comet-Images]
Sent: Monday, January 12, 2015 9:06 AM
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [Comet-Images] Comet Lovejoy and Extensive Nebulosity in Orion - Jan 11

Joe, that is a magnificent image. Can you tell how you froze the comet against the stationary starfield without artifacts on the dim part of the tail?

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com

Subject: [Comet-Images] Comet Lovejoy and Extensive Nebulosity in Orion - Jan 11

Date: Sunday, January 11, 2015, 3:02 PM

Taken from New Mexico Skies using an FSQ 106 and STL11K
camera.This 30-min single shot shows the comet
passing infront of extensive nebulosity in Orion
LINK

From:  Gianluca Masi 
Subject:  C/2014 Q2 Lovejoy: high-res mosaic (12 Jan. 2014)
Dear All,

a new image of comet C/2014 Q2 Lovejoy, captured remotely via the Virtual
Telescope Project. This is a three-panes mosaic, providing a nice resolution and
showing very subtle details in the tail

http://www.virtualtelescope.eu/2015/01/13/comet-c2014-q2-lovejoy-stunning-high-resolution-view-tail-12-jan-2015/

Best
Gianluca

Date:  Tue, 13 Jan 2015 10:09:24 -0800
From:  roman.kulesza@hotmail.com
Subject:  Comet C/2014 Q2 on 12Jan2015
Hi all,
Just like to share my picture from last night 12 /01/2014 at 22:45: 42 EST time ,
Was cold over here in Canada -Awenda Park -23C . Midland Ontario
I used my trust 10"inch at F-5 newton telescope and moded Canon Xsi camera ,
Just so simple picture ,like on beach , 2 minutes exposure JPG
I enjoy comet with my jaw down and short exposures :)
Did not go outside to change camera position ;)
so beautiful !
Comet C/2014Q2 https://www.flickr.com/photos/romanastrophotography/16086061639/

https://www.flickr.com/photos/romanastrophotography/16086061639/

Comet C/2014Q2 https://www.flickr.com/photos/romanastrophotography/16086061639/ Picture taken on 12 January 2015,was very cold -23 C ,10"inch at F-5 newton telescope,just JPG 2 minutes exposure ,22:45:42 EST time

View on www.flickr.com https://www.flickr.com/photos/romanastrophotography/16086061639/
Preview by Yahoo

Thanks God
all the best to you and Happy New Year
Roman

Date:  Tue, 13 Jan 2015 21:15:39 -0800
From:  jbrimaco@bigpond.net.au
Subject:  Comet C/2014 Q2 Lovejoy - One Hour Single Exposure - Jan 12
Taken from New Mexico Skies using an FSQ 106 refractor and STL11K camera
A single 60 min exposure.

LINKS

Positive image: https://www.flickr.com/photos/43846774@N02/16090736577/
Negative image: https://www.flickr.com/photos/43846774@N02/15656721303/
False color image: https://www.flickr.com/photos/43846774@N02/16250674276/

Clear, still skies
Joe

Joseph Brimacombe
Coral Towers Observatory

Cairns, Australia 

Date:  Wed, 14 Jan 2015 04:17:40 -0800
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Comet C/2014 Q2 Lovejoy - One Hour Single Exposure - Jan 12

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

On Tue, 1/13/15, jbrimaco@bigpond.net.au [Comet-Images] wrote:

Subject: [Comet-Images] Comet C/2014 Q2 Lovejoy - One Hour Single Exposure - Jan 12
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tuesday, January 13, 2015, 10:15 PM

Taken from New Mexico Skies using an FSQ 106 refractor
and STL11K cameraA single 60 min exposure.
LINKS
Positive image:
https://www.flickr.com/photos/43846774@N02/16090736577/Negative
image:
https://www.flickr.com/photos/43846774@N02/15656721303/False
color image:
https://www.flickr.com/photos/43846774@N02/16250674276/
Clear, still skiesJoe
Joseph BrimacombeCoral Towers
ObservatoryCairns,
Australia

Date:  Wed, 14 Jan 2015 14:04:42 +0100
From:  Gianluca Masi 
Subject:  C/2014 Q2 Lovejoy: high-res mosaic (13 Jan. 2014)
Dear All,

a new image of comet C/2014 Q2 Lovejoy, captured remotely via the Virtual
Telescope Project. This is a three-panes mosaic, providing a nice resolution and
showing very subtle details in the tail

http://www.virtualtelescope.eu/2015/01/14/comet-c2014-q2-lovejoy-stunning-mosaic-13-jan-2015/

Best
Gianluca

Date:  Wed, 14 Jan 2015 22:04:15 +0000
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet Lovejoy - High res mosaic (Jan 11th.)
Hi all,
Here is my best result to date on C/2014 Q2. Field of view is approx 3.5° x 2° and composed of three fields. Many fine streamers are visible emanating from the nucleus. Also interesting to note the tail is not blue coloured. The B image showed no greater contrast on the tail streamers than the G image.
http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2014_q2_2015_01_11dp.jpg
TOA150 with SBIG STL-11k. LRGB. Three frame mosaic.
Copyright: SEN/D.Peach.
Damian
 *************************************************
Web: http://www.damianpeach.com/
FB: http://www.facebook.com/peachastro
Email: dpeach_78@yahoo.co.uk
************************************************* 

Date:  Wed, 14 Jan 2015 23:23:38 +0100
From:  Emilio Gálvez 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Comet Lovejoy - High res mosaic (Jan 11th.)
Damian It is a pleasure to see a picture in which can appreciate the jets
in such detail.

I think there is too overexposed images without respecting the exposure
times imposed by the proper motion of the comet resulting in blurred images
that distort the beauty of this type of celestial bodies.

Congratulations on a more real like image.

Emilio

2015-01-14 23:04 GMT+01:00 Damian Peach dpeach_78@yahoo.co.uk

Date:  Wed, 14 Jan 2015 22:37:43 +0000
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Comet Lovejoy - High res mosaic (Jan 11th.)
Many thanks Emilio.
I agree, using many short exposures allows the very fine jets emanating from the nucleus to be clearly seen (such as also seen in some great images by Daniel and Gianluca recently.)

Damian

From: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 14 Jan 2015 22:04:15 +0000
Subject: [Comet-Images] Comet Lovejoy - High res mosaic (Jan 11th.)

Hi all,
Here is my best result to date on C/2014 Q2. Field of view is approx 3.5° x 2° and composed of three fields. Many fine streamers are visible emanating from the nucleus. Also interesting to note the tail is not blue coloured. The B image showed no greater contrast on the tail streamers than the G image.
http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2014_q2_2015_01_11dp.jpg
TOA150 with SBIG STL-11k. LRGB. Three frame mosaic.
Copyright: SEN/D.Peach.
Damian
*************************************************
Web: http://www.damianpeach.com/
FB: http://www.facebook.com/peachastro
Email: dpeach_78@yahoo.co.uk
*************************************************

Hi All

Image of comet C/2014 Q2 (Lovejoy) taken on January 13.8, 2015:

http://i.imgur.com/k4Fkflq.jpg

Mosaic of 2 unfiltered exposures, 60-sec each 0.15-m f/7.3 refractor + CCD
Remotely from MPC code I89 (Nerpio, Spain)

From:  Gerald Rhemann 
Subject:  2014Q2 January 14
Hello everybody

Nice images of this comet which are posted frequently here at this group. I
personally had only three observations in January - it just fit yesterday.
Anyway here are some previews in black and white and one final image in
color:

Date:  Thu, 15 Jan 2015 07:03:38 -0800
From:  mfortsm@aol.com
Subject:  Re: 2014Q2 January 14
The images are very nice Gerald. I will have clear skys according to the Sat. images but you and all the members have set the goal so high I can only hope to come close to what I have seen here. Thanks Gerald. Mike 
Date:  Thu, 15 Jan 2015 16:16:44 +0100
From:  "José J. Chambó" 
Subject:  Image C/2014 Q2 (Lovejoy)
Comet C/2014 Q2 (Lovejoy) on January 10, 2015 into a field of 6x8 degrees, this image shows a tail composed by several jets and extends as far as 5 degrees long. The coma with 40' diameter seems has taken a bluish tone against the green color that it had until now.
Location:Benali, Valencia (Spain) Tech data:Canon lens at 135mm. f/5.6 + Canon EOS 350D camera (19×240 sec. at ISO 1600)
Post link:http://cometografia.es/lovejoy-gran-campo/

Regards.
José J. Chambó (Valencia, Spain)blog: cometografia.es twitter: @PepeChambo 

Date:  Thu, 15 Jan 2015 07:58:17 -0800
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Comet Lovejoy - High res mosaic (Jan 11th.)
Damian, gorgeous shot - the tail is white for sure, I had the same experience last night with my 12 inch, the tail was equal in blue and green shots.

Chris Schur

Subject: [Comet-Images] Comet Lovejoy - High res mosaic (Jan 11th.)
To: "Anthony Wesley" , "w.leatherbarrow@sheffield.ac.uk" , "maple@amtelecom.net" , "bgcombs@cox.net" , "bakingsley@aol.com" , "Carl O'Biernes" , "Carlos Hernandez" , "cmh2nd@gmail.com" , "david@firework.com" , "david.tyler10@btinternet.com" , "park3232@bellsouth.net" , "Efrain Morales" , "Eric Ng" , "ian.sharp@websavvy.co.uk" , "jane.h.jones@jpl.nasa.gov" , "jim phillips" , "Jamie Cooper" , "Freddy Willems" , "Dave Eicher" , "nancy@universetoday.com"
Cc: "Mark Parrish" , "martin.mobberley@btinternet.com" , "mbakich@astronomy.com" , "Nick James" , "paul.abel@yahoo.co.uk" , "buzzard51@cox.net" , "takmewlonman@aol.com" , "pete.lawrence@digital-astronomy.co.uk" , "rvbest123321@aol.com" , "robin.scagell@gmail.com" , "swalker@SkyandTelescope.com" , "trevb@iinet.net.au" , "Wayne Jaeschke" , "William J. Stegeman" , "Μanos Kardasis" , "Martin Lewis" , "Peter Edwards" , "sigarro@btinternet.com" , "Callum Potter" , "jds@ast.cam.ac.uk"
, "buczynski8166@btinternet.com" , "Richard Miles" , "Guy Hurst" , "Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com" , "Tom Kerss" , "comet@aerith.net" , "Tom Boles" , "webmaster@spaceweather.com" , "Padma Yanamandra-Fisher" , "Gary Kronk" , "GarySeronik" , "Jerry Bonnell" , "Robert Nemiroff"
Date: Wednesday, January 14, 2015, 2:04 PM

Hi
all,
Here is my
best result to date on C/2014 Q2. Field of view is approx
3.5° x 2° and composed of three fields. Many fine
streamers are visible emanating from the nucleus. Also
interesting to note the tail is not blue coloured. The B
image showed no greater contrast on the tail streamers than
the G image.
http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2014_q2_2015_01_11dp.jpg
TOA150 with SBIG STL-11k. LRGB. Three frame
mosaic.
Copyright: SEN/D.Peach.
Damian
 *************************************************
Web: http://www.damianpeach.com/
FB: http://www.facebook.com/peachastro
Email: dpeach_78@yahoo.co.uk
************************************************* 

Date:  Thu, 15 Jan 2015 08:52:15 -0800
From:  michaeljaeger@gmx.at
Subject:  Color of Lovejoys tail
Hello

With interest I followed the discussion over red, brown and white gas tails
I can not confirm such colors.

My Kai-chip shows the tail more intense in blue.
The color separations in high contrast.

http://cometpieces-at.webnode.at/#a2014q220150115rgb-jpg http://cometpieces-at.webnode.at/#a2014q220150115rgb-jpg

Maybe this is also related to the sensors and filters?

I use Baader RGB

Regards
Michael Jäger

Date:  Thu, 15 Jan 2015 20:02:20 +0100
From:  Emilio Gálvez 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Color of Lovejoys tail
Hello Michael

I think is a mixture of both. The sensor is more sensitive in the blue and
baader filters overlap between blue and green being the most wide blue.

I enclose the graphs of transmission of the filters and the quantum
efficiency of the detector.

Regards

Emilio Gálvez

Date:  Thu, 15 Jan 2015 20:07:39 +0000
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Color of Lovejoys tail
Very interesting Michael.
Clearly the CCD and filter combination can make quite a noticeable difference (more so than i had thought.) Also the method employed to construct a colour image plays a part since most of us are using an LRGB composition to some degree. Certainly no two images seem to have quite the same colour, though in general the tail seems somewhere between white and pale blue given the majority of images.
Best Wishes
Damian

Date:  Fri, 16 Jan 2015 07:34:40 +0100
From:  francois Kugel 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Color of Lovejoys tail [2 Attachments]
Hello

Kai sensor is more sensitive in the green.
In my opinion, the best way torestore the color balance is to determine
the coefficients to be applied to the exposure time for each color
filter R, G and B. (same CCD, filters, collector, air mass) based on
photometric reference stars.

Francois

Date:  Fri, 16 Jan 2015 01:16:49 -0800
From:  michaeljaeger@gmx.at
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Color of Lovejoys tail
Dear Damian

I appreciate your work.

Back to questions. The difference between blue and green is not dramatic but available. Images with Astronomik filters show a weighting towards blue too. In the coming days I will make comparisons with Sensors Kai 11002 and KAF 6303.

Michael

Date:  Fri, 16 Jan 2015 04:33:46 -0800
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Comet 2014 Q2 - Getting too big to fit!   1/14/15
Greetings cometary friends,

Clear skies are back to Arizona, which means comet shooting every clear night. Also if you do remote shooting in New Mexico - youll be in luck for the next few days. This comet is getting too large for the big scope now, The head is getting so large it fills nearly the entire field. The nucleus appeared much more starlike this night, but seeing was average.

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/lovejoyQ2-011415.html

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com 

Date:  Fri, 16 Jan 2015 05:13:51 -0800

Ogg: [Comet-Images] 2014Q2 January 14 LRGB

Finally I processed and uploaded the color image taken on January 14th : http://www.astrostudio.at/2_Bright%20Comets.php?img=images/2_Bright%20Comets/275_2014Q2_14_01C.jpg best regards Gerald 

Date:  Fri, 16 Jan 2015 14:49:36 +0000
From:  denis buczynski 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 2014Q2 January 14 LRGB
Gerald,
This picture has to be considered to be the definition of a beautiful earth based comet image. It has it all, perfect sky transparency, perfect fast corrected optics,perfect focus, perfect tracking, perfect processing.Thanks for all the work in obtaining it and posting it for us to see.
Best wishes
Denis

Date:  Fri, 16 Jan 2015 10:54:02 -0600
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  [Comet-Images] 2014 Q2 on 2015 Jan 16th RED light
Two photos from last night (03:05 UT) taken at ASO, one wide field and another with
the 0.5m astrograph showing the tail structure just beyond the coma.
http://www.arksky.org/smf/index.php/topic,2440.msg11233.html#msg11233
The wide field is taken in RED light (Astrodon red) which exhibited far more tail
width and structure than did blue or green.

------------
Clay

Arkansas Sky Observatories
http://www.arksky.org/
ASO Petit Jean Mountain /MPC H41
ASO Petit Jean Mountain South /MPC H45
ASO West Conway /MPC H43
.......serving astronomy since 1971

Date:  Fri, 16 Jan 2015 13:24:15 -0800
From:  mfortsm@aol.com
Subject:  C/2014 Q2 - 01152015-mfh
Hello. TV127is - STF8300 - 2x180 sec each frame. I was having some high thin clouds and ground haze. No excuses because the f-5 just can't compete with the f1.5 and other super scopes for this kind of comet. If we got a comet like this a couple of times a year I would invest. Anyway good work everyone.
Mike

Date:  Sat, 17 Jan 2015 09:49:10 -0800
From:  kodama@alumni.caltech.edu
Subject:  Comet Lovejoy time-lapse - 15 Jan. 2015
Here are a couple of time-lapse clips of Comet Lovejoy, taken on Wednesday evening:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wj8g39uw-BA https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wj8g39uw-BA

and from later in the evening (I had to do a meridian flip):

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=n0O9OxCRD7s https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=n0O9OxCRD7s

Each video has a link below it to a negative version of the video which is a little easier to look at to see changes in the tail. Unfortunately, there was nothing dramatic going on.

The videos are a bit noisy because I was shooting at ISO 6400 to minimize smearing each frame (30 sec. long, 45 sec. apart)

Dave Kodama 

Date:  Sat, 17 Jan 2015 12:15:15 -0800
From:  michaeljaeger@gmx.at
Subject:  Comet Lovejoy LRGB Jan 12, 13, 14
Dear colleagues

The observation window in Austria is over. In the near future bad weather is expected.

Three LRGB recordings from 12, 13, 14 January
with APO 80/400 and Moravian G3-11002

I tried to use all available information of the comet.

Best Regards
Michael Jäger

Date:  Sat, 17 Jan 2015 19:35:44 -0800
From:  mfortsm@aol.com
Subject:  C/2014 Q2 - 01172015 - MFH
Hello. The comet seems to have poluted the entire sky around itself. What gets brighter seemes to get harder to process for me. The tail is dynamic and always a surprise from night to night. This is a little less than an hour old at the time of this post. TV127is - STF8300 - 2x frames of 300 sec exp each.
Mike H

Date:  Sat, 17 Jan 2015 19:45:26 -0800
From:  cheekygeek@gmail.com
Subject:  This newbies attempt at Lovejoy this evening


https://farm9.staticflickr.com/8565/16303458981_bd781442a9_o.jpg https://farm9.staticflickr.com/8565/16303458981_bd781442a9_o.jpg

https://farm9.staticflickr.com/8565/16303458981_bd781442a9_o.jpg

https://farm9.staticflickr.com/8565/16303458981_bd781442... https://farm9.staticflickr.com/8565/16303458981_bd781442a9_o.jpg

View on farm9.staticflickr.com https://farm9.staticflickr.com/8565/16303458981_bd781442a9_o.jpg
Preview by Yahoo

Desaturated and inverted: Previous image: Desaturated and inverted. https://www.flickr.com/photos/pixelsmithy/16304702892/

https://www.flickr.com/photos/pixelsmithy/16304702892/

Previous image: Desaturated and inverted. https://www.flickr.com/photos/pixelsmithy/16304702892/ Slightly cropped.

View on www.flickr.com https://www.flickr.com/photos/pixelsmithy/16304702892/
Preview by Yahoo

This image is the result of using my (manual focus) Tokina AT-X 90mm f2.5 Macro on a decidely non-macro subject this evening. I took several images and stacked them using DeepSkyStacker and then did some more messing in Photoshop with the resulting TIF. I lowered the contrast to pick up the tail (which, unless it is just my wishful thinking/imagination, can be seen all the way back to nearly beneath the Pleiades)!

Most of the images were 30 seconds or less at different ISOs (mostly 1600) and the camera and lens were mounted on a (roughly) polar-aligned Vixen Polarie for tracking during the exposures. Camera was a Pentax K-3.

Darren Addy
Alda, Nebraska 

Date:  Sat, 17 Jan 2015 23:46:57 -0800
From:  jbrimaco@bigpond.net.au
Subject:  Comet Lovejoy. One hour single exposure. Jan 16

Clear, still skies
Joe

Joseph Brimacombe
Coral Towers Observatory
Cairns, Australia

Date:  Sun, 18 Jan 2015 17:40:32 +0000
From:  Soulier Jean-FranÃ§ois 
Subject:  Observation of comets 20150117 and 18
Good evening.

50mm lens at F/D: 4, Atick 314L+, no filter between two holes
low clouds, from the Seine and Marne, France.
C 2014 Q2 Lovejoy
Tail: +/- 15 °, mosaic 2 images.
Unfortunately, small field rotation ... difficult to connect.
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/imageC2014Q2Lovejoyfrance.htm

T400RC Remote, SpaceObs, A.Maury, Chile :

53P Van Biesbroeck
Re-observation W96 (last reporting 20140310 mag : 20.6T by #G36)
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/image53PVanBiesbroeckChile.htm

10P Tempel
Re-observation W96 (last reporting 20140626 mag : 20.8T by #G96)
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/image10PTempelChile.htm

and 29P S-W1
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/image29PschwassmannwachmannChile.html

Sincerely.
SOULIER Jean-François
C10/FranceW96/Chile 

Date:  Sun, 18 Jan 2015 20:08:26 +0100
From:  francois Kugel 
Subject:  Comet Lovejoy RGB Jan 12.81 reprocessed
Hello,

Here is my RGB image reprocessed of Jan.12 considering the spectral
response (Landolt stars calibration)

LX 800-200/ ST2000XM (Kai)/RGB Astronomik filters
exposures : B= 20x30s, R= 14x30s, G= 8x30s bin2

zoom 0.5 :
http://lesia.obspm.fr/comets/lib/display-obs1.php?Num=13243

full size :
http://www.astrosurf.com/obsdauban/images/C14Q2/C14Q2-2015-01-1281-1260s-bin1-R420sG240sB600s-LXST2k.jpg

Best regards,
Francois 

Date:  Sun, 18 Jan 2015 19:40:04 +0000
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet Lovejoy - January 12th.
Hi all,
Here is a high resolution image of the comet from Jan 12th. Once again many streamers are visible in the tail, along with a rather turbulent looking region about half way along. Also faint nebulosity in the background.
http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2014_q2_2015_01_12dp.jpg
FSQ106 with STL-11k. LRGB image. Two frame mosaic.
Best Wishes
Damian

*************************************************
Web: http://www.damianpeach.com/
FB: http://www.facebook.com/peachastro
Email: dpeach_78@yahoo.co.uk
************************************************* 

Date:  Sun, 18 Jan 2015 21:26:44 +0100
From:  chrismlt@laposte.net
Subject:  Comet 15P Finlay in color, with details
Dear all,

I've been imaging comet Finlay by saturday evening, 2015 01 17.
It appears that much details can be seen now.

Photometric measures are :
m2 = 11.71 (standard aperture radius 11″), and mag 9.86 for aperture radius = 40″.
The comet shows a nice inner shell with some details inside (diameter = 2.8′ x 3.2′) within a larger coma that is 5.5′ in diameter. A blue ion tail is seen on heavily processed images : total lenght = 1° 10′ (70 arcmin).
Images taken with a FS102 refractor + foc. reducer = 641 mm focal lenght, 2015 01 17 from 17h53 to 18h27 UT. DSLR = 31 x 60sec exp. 3200 iso. Processing : Iris.

https://millimagjournal.wordpress.com/cometes/

Cheers,
Christophe

Date:  Sun, 18 Jan 2015 20:25:13 -0800
From:  cheekygeek@gmail.com
Subject:  Newbie gets some definition in Comet Lovejoy tail
Nearly ideal conditions (particularly for January) here in south-central Nebraska this evening. My strategy was to go for longer exposure times and lower my ISO to increase the dynamic range. Stack of 3 best 2 minute subs at ISO 200.

Pentax K-3, Tokina AT-X 90mm f2.5 Macro, Vixen Polarie on a home made wedge. Camera attached to Polarie with an Arca-Swiss p0 Monoball. Full resolution on Flickr.

Comments and criticism welcome in equal measure:

Comet Lovejoy C/2014 Q2 on Jan. 18, 2015 from Alda, Nebraska https://www.flickr.com/photos/pixelsmithy/16128751667/

https://www.flickr.com/photos/pixelsmithy/16128751667/

Comet Lovejoy C/2014 Q2 on Jan. 18, 2015 from Alda, N... https://www.flickr.com/photos/pixelsmithy/16128751667/ Upped my sub exposure time and lowered the ISO to increase dynamic range (ISO 200). Pentax K-3 with a Tokina AT-X 90mm f2.5 (wide open). Vixen Polarie ...

View on www.flickr.com https://www.flickr.com/photos/pixelsmithy/16128751667/
Preview by Yahoo

Comet Lovejoy C/2014 Q2 - Negative - Jan. 18, 2015 https://www.flickr.com/photos/pixelsmithy/16314607165/

https://www.flickr.com/photos/pixelsmithy/16314607165/

Comet Lovejoy C/2014 Q2 - Negative - Jan. 18, 2015 https://www.flickr.com/photos/pixelsmithy/16314607165/ Upped my sub exposure time and lowered the ISO to increase dynamic range (ISO 200). Pentax K-3 with a Tokina AT-X 90mm f2.5 (wide open). Vixen Polarie ...

View on www.flickr.com https://www.flickr.com/photos/pixelsmithy/16314607165/
Preview by Yahoo

Respectfully submitted,

Darren Addy
Alda, Nebraska

Date:  Mon, 19 Jan 2015 11:18:41 +0100
From:  "José J. Chambó" 
Subject:  Image C/2014 Q2 (Lovejoy)
Comet C/2014 Q2 (Lovejoy) on January 16, 2015 at its best. In this image, composed by a mosaic of three frames and covering a field of 7 x 3.5 degrees, the comet shows a powerful coma of 40' wide shinning at 4th magnitude. A long gassy tail is thrown toward East in which can be see several jets opening in angle. Manifold details are perceived in these streamers, ripples, knots and a disconnection at 2 degrees from nucleus.

Location:Remotely from Mayhill, New Mexico (USA) Tech data:Takahashi Takahashi FSQ Fluorite refractor + SBIG STL-11000M camera 3x(L:1×180 Bin1 + RGB:1x60 Bin2)
Post link:http://cometografia.es/mosaico-lovejoy-16ene2015/
Regards.
José J. Chambó (Valencia, Spain)blog: cometografia.es twitter: @PepeChambo

From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Lovejoy and M45
Nothing short of spectacular; what an incredible image, Michael.
Note the large pocket of ejecta centered in the middle of the tail, immediately following the coma.
There is an incredible amount of changing going on with this comet right now.
Very fine image; thanks for posting.

Dr. Clay

Date:  Mon, 19 Jan 2015 18:21:13 -0600
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Lovejoy and M45
Something that may be significant that I just spotted in your image, Michael and perhaps something worth considering:
http://spaceweathergallery.com/full_image.php?image_name=Michael-JAcger-2014q220150118mosaiklargeweb_1421711091.jpg
If you look along the length of the tail, you will first see the large obvious "bubble" of gas near the coma (est. 3 deg. from the coma).....then there is another....followed by another....and so on.
These are spaced nearly equidistant (~3 degrees apart) and you can see such enlargements or "bubbles" through the entire length of the tail.
Random thinking could suggest that some solid nucleus rotation with a specific point of emission could be responsible for such spacing over an extended period of time.
Nonetheless, whatever this seeming regularity might actually have as an origin is very interesting.

------------
Clay

Arkansas Sky Observatories
http://www.arksky.org/
ASO Petit Jean Mountain /MPC H41
ASO Petit Jean Mountain South /MPC H45
ASO West Conway /MPC H43
.......serving astronomy since 1971
____________________

Date:  Mon, 19 Jan 2015 21:02:05 -0600
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Comet Lovejoy naked eye January 20
Continuing updates on comet Lovejoy C/2014 Q2:
http://www.arksky.org/smf/index.php/topic,2440.msg11233.html#msg11233
As others have shown in beautiful detail, the morphology of this comet and its tail
continue to amaze every night.
In my opinion, there is redevelopment or increasing activity from only 3-4 days ago.

The comet is clearly visible tonight naked eye as a diffuse patch of light, with the
tail not visible naked eye nor with 10 x 50 binoculars under 6/6 skies at Arkansas
Sky Observatories.

------------
Clay

Arkansas Sky Observatories
http://www.arksky.org/
ASO Petit Jean Mountain /MPC H41
ASO Petit Jean Mountain South /MPC H45
ASO West Conway /MPC H43
.......serving astronomy since 1971

Date:  Tue, 20 Jan 2015 07:19:56 -0800
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  C2014Q2 - With Zeiss APO and DSLR - 1/18/19
Greetings all,

we have been battling high clouds all week here in Arizona, but a one hour clear hole came over and I was able to get a series of images. I dont often use my Hutech modded dSLR for comet long FL shots, but this one paid off since there was little time to get the host of color and L data this night. I first did a standard trailed stars composition this morning, and wanted to get this posted today. I have never seen a comet quite like this one! The tail streamers are awesome. Thanks for looking:

http://schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/lovejoyQ2-011815.html

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com 

Date:  Tue, 20 Jan 2015 17:07:04 +0100
From:  ligustri rolando 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C2014Q2 - With Zeiss APO and DSLR - 1/18/19
wow! very beautiful!

Rolando

we have been battling high clouds all week here in Arizona, but a one hour clear hole came over and I was able to get a series of images. I dont often use my Hutech modded dSLR for comet long FL shots, but this one paid off since there was little time to get the host of color and L data this night. Date:  Tue, 20 Jan 2015 09:42:27 -0800
From:  Orin Keplinger 
Subject:  RE: [Comet-Images] C2014Q2 - With Zeiss APO and DSLR - 1/18/19
Excellent pic, Chris.

  I am up near Mt. Shasta on holiday, and hoping tonight, after bridge, will be a "show stopper" like yours.

Sent from my U.S. Cellular® Smartphone

-------- Original message --------
From: "Chris Schur comets133@yahoo.com [Comet-Images]"
Date: 2015/01/20 07:19 (GMT-08:00)
To: Comet Group
Subject: [Comet-Images] C2014Q2 - With Zeiss APO and DSLR - 1/18/19

Greetings all,

we have been battling high clouds all week here in Arizona, but a one hour clear hole came over and I was able to get a series of images. I dont often use my Hutech modded dSLR for comet long FL shots, but this one paid off since there was little time to get the host of color and L data this night. I first did a standard trailed stars composition this morning, and wanted to get this posted today. I have never seen a comet quite like this one! The tail streamers are awesome. Thanks for looking:

http://schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/lovejoyQ2-011815.html

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com 

Date:  Tue, 20 Jan 2015 10:28:31 -0800
From:  mfortsm@aol.com
Subject:  %-Days
Images were reprocessed with new flats and adjusted with the same exposures and each one a 2x frames. Not perfect but about as close as I can get them. Each frame is a 300sec exp. The clouds are back and winter is returning.

http://www.fototime.com/7E9FFB66A819071/xlarge.jpg http://www.fototime.com/7E9FFB66A819071/xlarge.jpg

http://www.fototime.com/7E9FFB66A819071/xlarge.jpg

http://www.fototime.com/7E9FFB66A819071/xlarge.jpg http://www.fototime.com/7E9FFB66A819071/xlarge.jpg

View on www.fototime.com http://www.fototime.com/7E9FFB66A819071/xlarge.jpg

of the comet:

Continuing tail developments and changes are simply spectacular.

Date:  Wed, 21 Jan 2015 15:57:22 +0100
From:  "José J. Chambó" 
Subject:  Mosaic C/2014 Q2 (Lovejoy)
Comet C/2014 Q2 (Lovejoy) on January 17, 2015. Image composed by a mosaic of three frames and covering a field of 7 x 3.5 degrees, in those the comet shows a gassy full of changing details. Also can be detected a wide but very short dust tail departing from coma toward southeast.
Takahashi Takahashi FSQ Fluorite refractor + SBIG STL-11000M camera 3x(L:1×180 Bin1 + RGB:1x60 Bin2)Remotely from Mayhill, New Mexico (USA)
Post and image link:http://cometografia.es/mosaico-lovejoy-17ene2015/

Regards.
José J. Chambó (Valencia, Spain)blog: cometografia.es twitter: @PepeChambo

Date:  Wed, 21 Jan 2015 17:37:14 -0800
From:  jbrimaco@bigpond.net.au
Subject:  Comet Lovejoy and the Pleiades: Three Day Twenty Frame Mosaic - Jan 18, 19 and 20
I've put together three previous mosaics of Lovejoy during its encounter with M45.
The image comprises 20 x 30 min exposures.
All taken from New Mexico Skies with an FSQ 106 and STL11K

Positive image: https://www.flickr.com/photos/43846774@N02/15717151953/
Negative image: https://www.flickr.com/photos/43846774@N02/15714672174/

margin:0;padding:0 0 0 8px;}

#yiv4262598553 #yiv4262598553ygrp-text {
font-family:Georgia;}

#yiv4262598553 #yiv4262598553ygrp-text p {
margin:0 0 1em 0;}

#yiv4262598553 #yiv4262598553ygrp-text tt {
font-size:120%;}

#yiv4262598553 #yiv4262598553ygrp-vital ul li:last-child {
border-right:none !important;
}

#yiv4481718310 --
.yiv4481718310hmmessage P
{
margin:0px;padding:0px;}
#yiv4481718310 body.yiv4481718310hmmessage
{
font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri;}
#yiv4481718310

Comet C/2014 Q2 (Lovejoy) on January 17, 2015.
Image composed by a mosaic of three frames and covering a
field of 7 x 3.5 degrees, in those the comet shows a gassy
full of changing details. Also can be detected a wide but
very short dust tail departing from coma toward
southeast.
Takahashi
Takahashi FSQ Fluorite refractor + SBIG STL-11000M camera
3x(L:1×180 Bin1 + RGB:1x60 Bin2)Remotely from Mayhill, New Mexico
(USA)
Post
and image link:http://cometografia.es/mosaico-lovejoy-17ene2015/

Regards.
José
J. Chambó (Valencia,
Spain)blog: cometografia.es
twitter: @PepeChambo
#yiv4481718310 #yiv4481718310
--

-------- Original message --------
From: "Chris Schur comets133@yahoo.com
[Comet-Images]"
Date: 2015/01/20 07:19 (GMT-08:00)
To: Comet Group
Subject: [Comet-Images] C2014Q2 - With Zeiss APO and DSLR -
1/18/19

Greetings all,

we have been battling high clouds all week here in Arizona,
but a one hour clear hole came over and I was able to get a
series of images. I dont often use my Hutech modded dSLR
for comet long FL shots, but this one paid off since there
was little time to get the host of color and L data this
night. I first did a standard trailed stars composition
this morning, and wanted to get this posted today. I have
never seen a comet quite like this one! The tail streamers
are awesome. Thanks for looking:

http://schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/lovejoyQ2-011815.html

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Schur's Web Portal:
http://www.schursastrophotography.com

From: "Chris Schur
comets133@yahoo.com [Comet-Images]"


To: Comet
Group

Sent: Tuesday,
20 January 2015, 15:19
Subject: [Comet-Images]
C2014Q2 - With Zeiss APO and DSLR - 1/18/19

Greetings
all,

we have been battling high clouds all week here in Arizona,
but a one hour clear hole came over and I was able to get a
series of images. I dont often use my Hutech modded dSLR
for comet long FL shots, but this one paid off since there
was little time to get the host of color and L data this
night. I first did a standard trailed stars composition
this morning, and wanted to get this posted today. I have
never seen a comet quite like this one! The tail streamers
are awesome. Thanks for looking:

http://schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/lovejoyQ2-011815.html

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Schur's Web Portal:
http://www.schursastrophotography.com

From:  Josef Mueller 
Subject:  C/2014 Q2
Comet C/2014 Q2 (Lovejoy) on January 18, 2015 18:18h - 18:47h UT.
First image since a long time (weather!).
Astrophyics 130 mm Apo + SBIG ST-10XME camera.
30x40s
Irmtraut, Westerwald - Germany

http://www.westerwald-astro.de/jjm/kometen/c-20l4q2-hp.php

Josef Mueller A21

Sincerely.
SOULIER Jean-François
C10/France

Date:  Fri, 23 Jan 2015 13:29:28 +0000
From:  John Nassr 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Color of Lovejoys tail
Michael,
I too quietly wonder about "true" tail color and sometimes question if my processing techniques are terribly flawed. Especially when my images show a distinctly strong red while other imagers, like you, capture blue tails. I use a KAF8300 chip with a QE for LRGB at approximately 56, 33, 40, 33. Note that both red and blue are the least sensitive. Yet comparative images of my R,G, and B channels with identical exposure times show the tail red channel to be more prominent than blue, and about equal to green taken through both a Newtonian and apo refractor.

The KAI 11002 has a QE for LRGB at approximately 55, 35 42, 45 with blue being most sensitive. I viewed your comparative R,G, and B channels with exposure lengths to even out color sensitivity. Yet the tail in the red channel still looks weakest of the three. Your green tail, though more prominent than in red, is also weaker than blue.
John

On Friday, January 16, 2015 5:16 PM, "michaeljaeger@gmx.at [Comet-Images]" wrote:

  Dear Damian
I appreciate your work.

Back to questions. The difference between blue and green is not dramatic but available. Images with Astronomik filters show a weighting towards blue too. In the coming days I will  make comparisons with Sensors Kai 11002 and KAF 6303.
Best wishesMichael

Date:  Fri, 23 Jan 2015 07:43:18 -0600
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Color of Lovejoys tail
If you do a true color balance on the comet, rather than attempting to intensify its features - using the color indices of stars in the field - the tail color is indeed truly red.

------------
Dr. Clay

Arkansas Sky Observatories
http://www.arksky.org/
ASO Petit Jean Mountain /MPC H41
ASO Petit Jean Mountain South /MPC H45
ASO West Conway /MPC H43
.......serving astronomy since 1971

Subject: Re: [Comet-Images] Color of Lovejoys tail

Michael,

I too quietly wonder about "true" tail color and sometimes question if my processing techniques are terribly flawed. Especially when my images show a distinctly strong red while other imagers, like you, capture blue tails. I use a KAF8300 chip with a QE for LRGB at approximately 56, 33, 40, 33. Note that both red and blue are the least sensitive. Yet comparative images of my R,G, and B channels with identical exposure times show the tail red channel to be more prominent than blue, and about equal to green taken through both a Newtonian and apo refractor.

The KAI 11002 has a QE for LRGB at approximately 55, 35 42, 45 with blue being most sensitive. I viewed your comparative R,G, and B channels with exposure lengths to even out color sensitivity. Yet the tail in the red channel still looks weakest of the three. Your green tail, though more prominent than in red, is also weaker than blue.

John

On Friday, January 16, 2015 5:16 PM, "michaeljaeger@gmx.at [Comet-Im ages]" wrote:

Michael

From:  michaeljaeger@gmx.at
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Color of Lovejoys tail
John

I work with the KAF 8300 too and can confirm your impression. I believe that the filters play a significant role. The KAI-11002, the Baader blue and 2x2 mod. is for me the
best option at this comet. Why is this so? I do not know.

Michael

From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Update comet Lovejoy Jan 24 from ASO
Updated Jan 24 photo and data posted on the ASO summary of Comet Loveloy c/2014 Q2.
The multiple streamers are an impressive sight as the coma grows in diameter; the
comet was estimated at mag. 4.6 total via 10 x 50 binoculars.
http://www.arksky.org/smf/index.php/topic,2440

Date:  Sun, 25 Jan 2015 04:46:44 -0800
From:  jnassr2010@yahoo.com
Subject:  Finlay and lovejoy
Hi,

I have wanted to image Comet Finlay 15P for some time but weather did not permit. It was finally clear last night with the comet around 2 degrees from a four day old moon that caused reflections inside my telescope tube. The height of this 13 minute exposure is just less than one degree.

http://stardustobservatory.org/upload/comets/Finlay15PJan242015N8f4LRGB4333x1min3x32degreesfrom4daymoon-Nassr_20150124182557.jpg http://stardustobservatory.org/upload/comets/Finlay15PJan242015N8f4LRGB4333x1min3x32degreesfrom4daymoon-Nassr_20150124182557.jpg

http://stardustobservatory.org/upload/comets/Finlay15PJan242015N8f4LRGB4333x1min3x32degreesfrom4daymoon-Nassr_20150124182557.jpg

http://stardustobservatory.org/upload/comets/Finlay15PJa... http://stardustobservatory.org/upload/comets/Finlay15PJan242015N8f4LRGB4333x1min3x32degreesfrom4daymoon-Nassr_20150124182557.jpg

View on stardustobservatory.org http://stardustobservatory.org/upload/comets/Finlay15PJan242015N8f4LRGB4333x1min3x32degreesfrom4daymoon-Nassr_20150124182557.jpg
Preview by Yahoo

Comet Lovejoy C2014 Q2 is still an easily spotted naked eye object. Its tail is still very prominent after over two weeks past closest approach to the Sun. This 18 minute exposure is 4 degrees wide.

http://stardustobservatory.org/upload/comets/Lovejoy2014Q2Jan24201577EDf43683LRGB3111x3min-Nassr_20150124183620.jpg http://stardustobservatory.org/upload/comets/Lovejoy2014Q2Jan24201577EDf43683LRGB3111x3min-Nassr_20150124183620.jpg

John

From:  David Strange 
Subject:  C/2014 Q2 Nuclear detail
C/2014 Q2 imaged 2015-01-24 20:57h UT 120x30sec C8 Hyperstar + SXV-H9C.
Coma reprocessed with Larson -Sekanina filter and overlaid on
original image to show nuclear detail.

Date:  Sun, 25 Jan 2015 18:06:32 +0100
From:  Erik Bryssinck 
Subject:  comet LOVEJOY 24 jan. 2015
Hi all,

Observations of comet C/2014 Q2 (LOVEJOY) of jan 21st

Possible minor outburst on 20 or January 21 as a small jump in Af(rho)
number was determined. On 19 january, the Af(rho) value (according to CARA
approach) was about 4950 cm while last night (24 jan.) Af (rho) value was
approximately 5800 cm. The off (rho) today number is then slightly decreased
to about 5200 cm. Unfortunately, there is no data for 20 and January 21st.
An analysis of the Af(rho) value since early November briefly worked, we
hope to finish by the end of next week.

Observations last night:


http://www.astronomie.be/erik.bryssinck/c2014q2_20150124_b96.html

other observations:

http://www.astronomie.be/erik.bryssinck/c2014q2.html

___________________________________

kind regards,

Erik Bryssinck

BRIXIIS Observatory (MPC:B96)

http://www.astronomie.be/erik.bryssinck/

___________________________________

CARA - Cometary Archive for Af(rho) : http://cara.uai.it

VVS - Belgian association for amateur astronomers : http://www.vvs.be

Date:  Sun, 25 Jan 2015 19:31:03 -0800
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Finally - Comet Finlay 15P  1/24/15
Clear skies once again returned to Arizona this weekend, and up at our second observatory at 7000 feet elevation, the skies were very transparent and dark despite the thin crescent moon. This is with our Orion 8" f/4 astrograph, and Baader MPCC coma corrector. Exposure was 30 mins with my Canon DSLR set for ASA800.

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/Finlay012415.html

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com 

Date:  Sun, 25 Jan 2015 19:47:17 -0800
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 2014Q2 three panel color mosaic January 18
Gerald, that has to be your best Lovejoy yet. I know the amount of work involved is huge, I am very impressed.

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com

Subject: [Comet-Images] C/2014 Q2 Nuclear detail

C/2014 Q2  imaged
2015-01-24  20:57h UT  120x30sec C8
Hyperstar  + SXV-H9C.
Coma reprocessed with Larson -Sekanina filter and overlaid
on
original image to show nuclear detail.

https://www.dropbox.com/s/ktykn5f5k44id5e/2014Q2_20150124_dgs10.jpg?dl=0

David

Subject:  C/2014 Q2 Lovejoy: high-res mosaic (13 Jan. 2014)
Dear All,

after more than 10 days of bad wheater, a new image of comet C/2014 Q2 Lovejoy,
captured remotely via the Virtual Telescope Project. This is a three-panes mosaic:

http://www.virtualtelescope.eu/2015/01/25/comet-c2014-q2-lovejoy-stunning-mosaic-24-jan-2015/

Best
Gianluca

Good morning.

T400RC Remote, SpaceObs., A.Maury, Chile :

C 2014 AA52 CATALINA,
Tail : +/- 3.53', Coma : +/- 22"
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/imageC2014AA52CatalinaChile.htm

C 2013 G7 Mc NAUGHT
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/imageC2013G7McNaughtChile.htm

C 2014 W11 PANSTARRS, +2 mag. 15.7 m2 (MPC = m1 : 17.7).
Tail : +/-1.09', Coma : +/-15"
20150125 at 26
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/imageC2014W11PanstarrsChile.htm

http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/image4PFayeChile.htm

http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/imageC2013C2TenagraChile.htm

Date:  Mon, 26 Jan 2015 09:35:18 +0000
From:  David Strange 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2014 Q2 Nuclear detail
Thanks Chris. Yes, I recall Holmes looking like
the filament of an old light bulb, but I think
the jets of Hyakutake were the most memorable with this technique.
So long as its used with jurisprudence! There
have been so many fantastic images of the tail
detail but these have all been to the detriment of the blown out coma.
It will be interesting to see if we can record
jet details in 67P/C-G that may/may not be
confirmed with Rosetta images when it reaches perihelion later in the year.

David

Date:  Tue, 27 Jan 2015 00:36:42 +0100
From:  Lorenzo Comolli 
Subject:  Waves moving in the tail of Lovejoy
Dear list,
here is an animation of the waves moving in the tail of comet Lovejoy.
Imaged last Saturday from Italian Apennines at 1500 m heigth, with my TEC140 + SBIG 11k, L filter. 5 min exp, comet tracking.
24 Jan 2015 from 17.47 to 21.39 UT (~4 h)

http://www.astrosurf.com/comolli/temp/va_lovejoy_TEC140+11k_L_300s_ANIMATE_BIS_el2_hd1200.gif

Enjoy,
Lorenzo

Date:  Tue, 27 Jan 2015 01:10:40 +0100
From:  "José J. Chambó" 
Subject:  Comet Lovejoy and Pleiades
Comet C/2014 Q2 (Lovejoy) on January 17, 2015 approaching to 8 deg. from Pleiades star cluster (M 45). Still shining at its maximun around 4th magnitude, its ionic tail with more than 11 deg. long extends beyond the field limits of this image.
Canon lens at 95mm. f/5.6 + Canon EOS 100D camera (4×300 sec. at ISO 1600)From Los Giles - Olba, Teruel (Spain)
Post and image link:http://cometografia.es/lovejoy-pleyades/

Regards.
José J. Chambó (Valencia, Spain)blog: cometografia.es twitter: @PepeChambo

Date:  Tue, 27 Jan 2015 12:46:02 +0100
From:  Alfons Diepvens 
Subject:  C23 -NEW images 24 Jan. 2015 : a possible rotation of the nucleus ??!!


NEW images 24 Jan. 2015
C2014 Q2 Lovejoy - animation of nucleus rotation
2 frames animation

NEW images 26 Jan. 2015
C2014 Q2 Lovejoy - animation of nucleus rotation

4 frames animation,
there can be seen a possible rotation of the nucleus ??!!

4 frame animation
- 18h 51m UT (stack of 27 images)
- 19h 50m UT (stack of 23 images)
- 20h 54m UT (stack of 70 images)
- 23h 36m UT (stack of 70 images)

with a direct link to the image:
http://www.astronomie.be/alfons.diepvens/cometimages/index.html

Alfons Diepvens

Date:  Wed, 28 Jan 2015 07:11:25 -0800
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] image comet LOVEJOY on 25 jan.
Erik, thats about what I got on the 24th, one day earlier. It seems that the sharp rays are gone, and we now have several diffuse low surface brightness bands to see.

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Date:  Wed, 28 Jan 2015 07:17:24 -0800
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C23 -NEW images 24 Jan. 2015 : a possible rotation of the nucleus ??!!
Alfons, Im not convinced Im seeing rotation, its so hard with all the black and white star trails flashing on and off! Have you tried just HPF this image in PS? you can get the same info without the rotation of the stars.
Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com

On Tue, 1/27/15, Alfons Diepvens alfons.diepvens@telenet.be [Comet-Images] wrote:

Subject: [Comet-Images] C23 -NEW images 24 Jan. 2015 : a possible rotation of the nucleus ??!!
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, rastreadoresdecometas@gmail.com, "Van Loo Frans"
Date: Tuesday, January 27, 2015, 3:46 AM

NEW images 24 Jan. 2015
C2014 Q2 Lovejoy - animation of nucleus rotation
2 frames animation

NEW images 26 Jan. 2015
C2014 Q2 Lovejoy - animation of nucleus rotation

4 frames animation,
there can be seen a possible rotation of the nucleus ??!!

  4 frame animation
- 18h 51m UT (stack of 27 images)
- 19h 50m UT (stack of 23 images)
- 20h 54m UT (stack of 70 images)
- 23h 36m UT (stack of 70 images)

with a direct link to the image:
http://www.astronomie.be/alfons.diepvens/cometimages/index.html

jets is easier to see!

alfons

Date:  Wed, 28 Jan 2015 20:23:29 +0100
From:  Alfons Diepvens 
Subject:  Re: [comets-ml] Significant outburst of Comet 17P/Holmes


I confirm this outburst of 17P Holmes !!!

NEW images 28 Jan. 2015

17P Holmes - In OUTBURST !

with a direct link to the image:
http://www.astronomie.be/alfons.diepvens/cometimages/index.html

Alfons Diepvens

>It appears that Comet 17P/Holmes has undergone a significant
>outburst on 2015 January 26 possibly reaching 14th magnitude. If
>confirmed, this outburst will be the most energetic event of its
>kind since this comet's mega-outburst of 2007 October 23.
>
>Two 120-sec exposures through an SDSS-r' filter taken by the 2.0-m
>Faulkes Telescope North on January 28.25 show an extended coma some
>10-12 arcsec in diameter with possible outflows at p.a. 20 deg and
>270 deg. Seeing in the images is estimated to be in the range
>1.0-1.4 arcsec. The FITS images are not yet available (these require
>24 hours to come online) and so accurate photometry cannot yet be performed.
>
>Two previous 120-sec exposures through an SDSS-r' filter taken with
>the same 2.0-m Faulkes Telescope North on January 26.29 show 17P to
>be entirely quiescent at around 17-18th magnitude.
>
>Further results to follow.
>
>Observations of 17P are strongly encouraged.
>
>The results reported here are made possible thanks to the Las
>Cumbres Observatory Global Telescope Network (LCOGT).
>
>Richard Miles
>
>British Astronomical Association 

Date:  Wed, 28 Jan 2015 12:17:21 -0800
From:  jbrimaco@bigpond.net.au
Subject:  Comet Lovejoy Widefield Jan 26
Taken from New Mexico Skies with an FSQ 106 abd STL11K.
Getting low on the horizon at moonset.

Positive image: https://www.flickr.com/photos/43846774@N02/15764718094/
Negative image: https://www.flickr.com/photos/43846774@N02/16385431911/
False color image: https://www.flickr.com/photos/43846774@N02/16200949419/

Clear, still skies
Joe

Joseph Brimacombe
Coral Towers Observatory

Cairns, Australia

From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet Lovejoy - January 20th.
Hi all,
Here is an image of C/2014 Q2 from January 20th. Once again a dramatic tail with many fine streamers visible.
http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2014_q2_2015_01_20dp.jpg
FSQ106 with STL-11k. LRGB image. Two frame mosaic.

Damian

proud to protect the dust around at processing the data:

Date:  Thu, 29 Jan 2015 07:46:40 -0800
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 2014Q2 and M 45
Gerald, what a fantastic tail! Can you believe all the ribbons in the tail? I see the "galactic cirrus" in your shot clearly. A very difficult processing job to get that and still match the frames to make a panorama. Im impressed.

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com

Date:  Thu, 29 Jan 2015 21:15:13 +0000
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Comet Lovejoy - January 20th.
Many thanks Chris. Its been a lovely object hasn't it? Ive seen photos from every corner of the globe from people of every experience level. I had hoped in the early days this comet would surpass C/2013 R1 which was a lovely object, and this has more than delivered.
I'm sure the show isn't over yet. Hopefully it will remain a nice object for the weeks to come.
Damian

Date:  Fri, 30 Jan 2015 16:56:07 -0800
From:  jbrimaco@bigpond.net.au
Subject:  Comet Lovejoy Narrowfield L - Jan 30
Taken from Warrumbungle Observatory near Siding Spring, Australia, using a 41-cm RCOS and U9000 camera.
20 x 0.5 min images with comet 10 degrees above horizon and bright moonlight.

Positive image: https://www.flickr.com/photos/43846774@N02/16218794850/
Negative image: https://www.flickr.com/photos/43846774@N02/15783723674/
False color image: https://www.flickr.com/photos/43846774@N02/15786155003/

Clear, still skies
Joe

Joseph Brimacombe
Coral Towers Observatory

Cairns, Australia

Date:  Sat, 31 Jan 2015 15:15:34 +0100
From:  Gianluca Masi 
Subject:  C/2014 Q2 Lovejoy: high-res mosaic (30 Jan. 2014)
Dear All,

here it is a new image of comet C/2014 Q2 Lovejoy, captured remotely via the
Virtual Telescope Project. Severe lunar interference. This is a two-panes mosaic:

http://www.virtualtelescope.eu/2015/01/31/comet-c2014-q2-lovejoy-mosaic-30-jan-2015-perihelion-day/

We wish to dedicate this image to Martino Nicolini, a good friend, great comet
lover and observer. We will miss him. Ciao Martino!

Best
Gianluca 

Date:  Sat, 31 Jan 2015 15:53:45 +0100
From:  Gianluca Masi 
Subject:  17P/Holmes in outburst: an image
Dear All,

here it is an image of comet 17P, captured last night via the Virtual Telescope
Project:

http://www.virtualtelescope.eu/2015/01/31/comet-17pholmes-image-outburst-30-jan-2015/

Regards,
Gianluca

Diese E-Mail wurde von Avast Antivirus-Software auf Viren geprüft.
http://www.avast.com 
Date:  Sun, 01 Feb 2015 17:33:46 -0800
From:  hiroc070717@yahoo.com
Subject:  Triple frames of C/2014 Q2 Lovejoy January 24, 2015
Hi members,

Focal length 385mm: https://www.flickr.com/photos/hiroc/16385195795/
F.L. 135mm: https://www.flickr.com/photos/hiroc/16205807059/
F.L. 50mm: https://www.flickr.com/photos/hiroc/16399110672/

The movement of the tail was observed as 3.5 degrees par day against the core,
and it was calculated as about 6 million km/day.
The movement was far slower than that of solar wind, about 400km/s at the date.

Thank you for looking.
Hisayoshi Kato

Date:  Fri, 06 Feb 2015 13:58:22 -0000
From:  Martin Mobberley 
Subject:  Re: 2014 Q2 on 2015 Feb 6th via itel New Mexico
Thanks Chris. Nothing special re. flats. The standard itel calibration
files were used, but the field is only 155' x 92'. That's only 24 x 14mm
on the chip: quite small for an FSQ 106, so no vignetting.

Martin

>Very detailed shot Martin for such a short 3m exposure. Field looks flat to the edges, are you
>doing flats for these?

Date:  Sat, 07 Feb 2015 06:47:13 -0800
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  LovejoyQ2 - 2/6/15 - Last nights 1h20m of darkness...
Hello all,

this comet still has a magnificent ion tail, I did a full set of cal frames, lums and color last night just before the moon rose. Then for good measure, I did more darks. Here is just the L data, combined as a average on the nucleus. The color data and stationary image is coming next...

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/lovejoyQ2-020615.html

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Subject: [Comet-Images] Re: 2014 Q2 on 2015 Feb 9th via itel New Mexico
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Date: Monday, February 9, 2015, 5:19 AM

Thanks Chris. Well, the raw
background is a bit noisy with
only 3 mins, but I guess the simple answer is that
New Mexico skies must be really DARK for 3 mins to work!

I just mixed in 3 x 60s of colour data to the previous
shot:

http://martinmobberley.co.uk/images/2014q2_20150209_0317_mpm.jpg

Regards,
Martin

anything."
I happed to think the image is very nice from a study standpoint.

Date:  Mon, 09 Feb 2015 09:19:00 -0800
From:  jbrimaco@bigpond.net.au
Subject:  Comet Lovejoy Five Frame Widefield Mosaic - Feb 8
Taken from New Mexico Skies using an FSQ 106 telescope and STL11K camera.
Five frame mosaic. 20 min exposures. Luminance filter.

LINKS

Positive image: https://www.flickr.com/photos/43846774@N02/16456586196/
Negative image: https://www.flickr.com/photos/43846774@N02/16296334979/
False color image: https://www.flickr.com/photos/43846774@N02/16481646712/

Clear, still skies
Joe

Joseph Brimacombe
Coral Towers Obsrvatory

Cairns, Australia

From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet Lovejoy with NGC 891 (Feb 4th.)
Hi all,

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2014_q2_2015_02_04dp.jpg FSQ106 with STL-11k. LRGB. 2 frame mosaic.

Date:  Fri, 13 Feb 2015 04:26:24 -0800
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  A quick shot of LovejoyQ2 from Wednesday evening 2/11
Greetings all,

As the comet sets more in the west each day, the trees to the west of the observatory now only allow an hour of shooting before its gone. This was taken in that hour, and really shows how the comet has slowed over the past few weeks:

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/lovejoyQ2-021115.html

THanks for looking!

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com 

Date:  Fri, 13 Feb 2015 06:40:15 -0800
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 2014 Q2 on 2015 Feb 13th via itel New Mexico
Awesome Martin! Look at those sharp tail rays very near the head, The comet is still changing so fast, hard to keep up.

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com

Date:  Mon, 16 Feb 2015 22:40:32 +0000
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet Lovejoy (Jan 17th.)
Hi all,
One of two sets of data i hadn't processed. The is a starless median stack. It really works well to show the tail streamers very clearly. A disconnection event seems to have occurred.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2014_q2_2015_01_17dp.jpg
150mm F7 with STL-11k. Unfiltered. 2 frame mosaic. 5x2mins each.
Best Wishes
Damian
 *************************************************
Web: http://www.damianpeach.com/
FB: http://www.facebook.com/peachastro
Email: dpeach_78@yahoo.co.uk
*************************************************

Comet 15P/Finlay imaged on January 23, 2015.

GSO 8" @ f/3,8 reflector + Canon EOS-100D camera (1x180 sec. @ ISO 400)Vallés, Valencia (Spain)
Post and image link:http://cometografia.es/15p-finlay-23ene2015/

Date:  Tue, 17 Feb 2015 07:34:14 -0800
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 2014Q2 Feb 13 color
Gerald, thats one of the best youve posted on this comet I think. The rich blue hues, fine tail details and sharp stars are a testament to your imaging skills. There is a nice reveiw of the new 3" dia Televue coma corrector in the upcoming april sky and telescope, That may make it possible to make a system fast like yours for a reasonable cost.

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com

Date:  Tue, 17 Feb 2015 18:11:37 -0800
From:  jbrimaco@bigpond.net.au
Subject:  Comet C/2014 Q2 Lovejoy Narrowfield C - Feb 7
Taken from New Mexico Skies Observatory using an 51-cm RCOS and STXL-6303 camera on a PME II mount.
Time: 06h 26m UT; 28 x 1 min exposures; binned 2x2
NOTE
Low altitude
LINK

Time: 02h 21m UT; 1 x 20 min exposure

Hello everybody,

I revisited my image data of Feb 13 and combined the 2 panel mosaic:

http://www.astrostudio.at/2_Bright%20Comets.php?img=images/2_Bright%20Comets
/289_2014Q2_13_02_M.jpg

Looks like a copy of the image Jan 21 :

http://www.astrostudio.at/2_Bright%20Comets.php?img=images/2_Bright%20Comets
/280_2014Q2_21_01C.jpg

best regards

Gerald 

Date:  Thu, 19 Feb 2015 12:36:42 +0000
From:  Michael Oates 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 2014Q2 mosaic image feb 13 compared to jan 21
Gerald,

As always, your images are fantastic!

Where you indicate the exposures such as:
Exposure time: LRGB 800/600/600/600 sec.each panel

Does this mean a single frame exposure of 600 sec or is that the integrated time of a
number of shorter exposures.

Thanks,

Mike

Date:  Thu, 19 Feb 2015 21:02:50 -0800
From:  jbrimaco@bigpond.net.au
Subject:  Comet C/2014 Q2 Lovejoy near the Star Psi Perseus and Planetary Nebula The Little Dumbbell or M76 Five Frame Widefield Mosaic L - Feb 18, 2015
Taken from New Mexico Skies using an FSQ 106 telescope and STL11K camera.
5 x 20 min exposures.

LINK

Positive image: https://www.flickr.com/photos/43846774@N02/16585540851/
Negative image: https://www.flickr.com/photos/43846774@N02/15966981673/
False color image: https://www.flickr.com/photos/43846774@N02/16585584961/

Clear still skies
Joe

Joseph Brimacombe
Coral Towers Observatory
Cairns, Australia 

Date:  Fri, 20 Feb 2015 09:14:39 +0100
From:  "José J. Chambó" 
Subject:  C/2014 Q2 (Lovejoy) on February 13
Comet C/2014 Q2 (Lovejoy) on February 13, 2015. Entering into Milky Way zone of Cassiopeia, its brightness has dropped until 5th magnitude while its tail of 4.5 deg. length shows a disconnection.
Location:Hoya Redonda, Valencia (Spain) Tech data:Canon lens at 135mm. f/5.6 & Canon EOS 100D camera (6×300 sec. at ISO 1600)
Post and image link:http://cometografia.es/lovejoy-entra-via-lactea/

Regards.
José J. Chambó (Valencia, Spain)blog: cometografia.es twitter: @PepeChambo 

Date:  Fri, 20 Feb 2015 09:44:56 -0000
From:  Martin Mobberley 
Subject:  2014 Q2 on 2015 Feb 20th via itel New Mexico
Comet Lovejoy close-up from approx. 7 hours ago.
M76 visible in the top left.

http://martinmobberley.co.uk/images/2014q2_20150220_0220_mpm.jpg

Regards,
Martin

Comet page:

http://martinmobberley.co.uk/Comets.html

From:  "José J. Chambó"

To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
From: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 19 Feb 2015 17:08:41 +0100
Subject: [Comet-Images] C2012Q2 Dec - February high res photo print

Hi all, This is a review of 11 mosaic images taken December, January, February. Full resolution is 52718x11812 I made a 4,5x1meter photoprint – looks great. http://www.astrostudio.at/2_Bright%20Comets.php?img=images/2_Bright%20Comets/290_Mosaic.jpg best regards Gerald 


Date:  Fri, 20 Feb 2015 13:05:12 +0100

Gerald

Betreff: Re: [Comet-Images] 2014Q2 mosaic image feb 13 compared to jan 21

Gerald,

As always, your images are fantastic!

Where you indicate the exposures such as:
Exposure time: LRGB 800/600/600/600 sec.each panel

Does this mean a single frame exposure of 600 sec or is that the integrated time of a
number of shorter exposures.

Thanks,

Mike

>

Date:  Fri, 20 Feb 2015 10:16:57 -0800
From:  jbrimaco@bigpond.net.au
Subject:  Comet C/2014 Q2 Lovejoy plus Dislocation Event and the Little Dumbbell Nebula Widefield L False Color - Feb 20, 2015
Taken from New Mexico Skies using an FSQ 106 telescope and STL11K camera.
1 x 20 min exposure; luminance filter

LINK
Positive image: https://www.flickr.com/photos/43846774@N02/16592151432/
Negative image: https://www.flickr.com/photos/43846774@N02/16406954979/

Clear, still skies
Joe

Coral Towers Observatory

Cairns, Australia

Date:  Sun, 22 Feb 2015 22:13:35 +0100
From:  "José J. Chambó" 
Subject:  C/2014 Q2 (Lovejoy) on February 20
On February 20th of 2015, comet C/2014 Q2 (Lovejoy) had a approach to the planetary nebula M 76, the "Little Dumbbell".
Location:Remotely from Mayhill, New Mexico (USA) Tech data:Planewave 20" CDK reflector & FLI-PL11002M camera (L:4×120 Bin1 + RGB:1x60 Bin2)
Post and image link:http://cometografia.es/lovejoy-junto-pequena-dumbbell/

Regards.
José J. Chambó (Valencia, Spain)blog: cometografia.es twitter: @PepeChambo 

Date:  Sun, 22 Feb 2015 23:11:01 +0000
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet Lovejoy (Feb 19th)

Here is C/2014 Q2 on Feb 19th. M76 again in the field.
http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2014_q2_2015_02_19dp.jpg
Best Wishes
Damian

#yiv8380623836ygrp-text tt {font-size:120%;}#yiv8380623836 #yiv8380623836ygrp-vital ul li:last-child {border-right:none !important;}#yiv8380623836 


Date:  Sun, 22 Feb 2015 23:20:45 -0800
From:  jbrimaco@bigpond.net.au
Subject:  Comet Lovejoy and M76 - Feb 22

1 x 20 min exposure through thin high cloud using a luminance filter

On Monday, February 23, 2015 5:13 AM, "José J. Chambó jjchambo@hotmail.com [Comet-Images]" wrote:

On February 20th of 2015, comet C/2014 Q2 (Lovejoy) had a approach to the planetary nebula M 76, the "Little Dumbbell".Location:Remotely from Mayhill, New Mexico (USA) Tech data:Planewave 20" CDK reflector & FLI-PL11002M camera (L:4×120 Bin1 + RGB:1x60 Bin2)Post and image link:http://cometografia.es/lovejoy-junto-pequena-dumbbell/Regards.José J. Chambó (Valencia, Spain)blog: cometografia.es twitter: @PepeChambo

Subject:  comet C/2014 Q2 Lovejoy 19-20 /02/2015
The idea was to make a mosaic on the 4gg, but because the weather we are not
successful, sin. public anyway the same this mosaic: comet C/ 2014Q2 Lovejoy in the
days February 19 and 20, notice how change the tail of ions

http://www.astrobin.com/full/159165/0/

SOULIER Jean-François
C10/France
