Date:  Sat, 21 Nov 2015 02:16:16 +0000
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Comet 67P - Churyumov Gerasimenko this morning
Hello all,

Seeing was poor near the horizon, however the transparency was very good and I was able to record a reasonable amount of tail detail in this dim comet. This is an hour and 6 mins total integration time with my 12.5" newt:

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/cg112015.html

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com 

Date:  Sat, 21 Nov 2015 06:07:58 -0800
From:  hiroc070717@yahoo.com
Subject:  C/2013 US10 Catalina November 20, 2015UTC
The comet looked mere a blob of light with no tail at the moment.

I tired imaging of the comet through narrow window of clouds near the horizon.
The altitude of the object was around one degree just after the beginning of twilight.
Stars trailed due to atmospheric refraction.
Exposure was around 20:00 November 20, 2015UTC or 5:00 November 21, 2015JST.

C/2013 US10 Catalina in Virgo November 20, 2015UTC https://www.flickr.com/photos/hiroc/22547834243/

https://www.flickr.com/photos/hiroc/22547834243/

C/2013 US10 Catalina in Virgo November 20, 2015UTC https://www.flickr.com/photos/hiroc/22547834243/ I tried imaging of the comet through cloud window near the horizon just after the beginning of twilight. The altitude of the object was around one degree. The obj...

View on www.flickr.com https://www.flickr.com/photos/hiroc/22547834243/
Preview by Yahoo

Thank you for looking.

Hisayoshi Kato in Tokyo 

Date:  Sun, 22 Nov 2015 13:51:36 +0000
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Comet Catalina US10 from northern Arizona this morning...
Hello all,

very difficult observation on this one, visually with the 80mm and 35mm panoptic occular it was a round slightly condensed object, with no sign of the twin tails that show up in the images. After five minutes, we lost it visually as it was 2 degrees up in bright twilight. IMages show it for a longer time, and a beautiful emerald green head with two tails forming a Y shaped fan.

I just posted these on Space weather, I hope they put the images in the blanks:

http://spaceweathergallery.com/indiv_upload.php?upload_id=120181

If not, go to the space weather.com gallery and Ive put it there!
Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com 

Date:  Sun, 22 Nov 2015 12:49:56 -0700

Date:  Sun, 22 Nov 2015 22:16:21 +0100
From:  "José J. Chambó" 
Subject:  22P/Kopff on Nov. 6
Object/Date:Comet 22P/Kopff @ November 6, 2015
Description:Comet 22P/Kopff imaged on November 6th 2015 placed between constellations of Sagittarius and Ophiuchus just into Milky Way, can be seen in the middle of this image with a brightness of magnitude 11 and a small bluish coma of only 2 arcminutes wide.
Location:Benali, Valencia (Spain) Tech data:GSO 8" @ f/3.8 reflector & Canon EOS-100D camera (4x120 sec. at ISO 800) cropped
Post and image link:http://cometografia.es/22p-kopff-20151106/

Regards.
José J. Chambó (Valencia, Spain)blog: cometografia.es twitter: @PepeChambo

Date:  Tue, 24 Nov 2015 14:08:13 -0800
From:  michaeljaeger@gmx.at
Subject:  C/2013 US10 Nov.24 LRGB
Comet low 5° Nov 24 4.45 UT 8"/2.8 FLI 8300
L-2x120 UV/IR 1x120 green 1x120 blue 4x120 red
Weißenkirchen Austria

http://spaceweathergallery.com/full_image.php?image_name=Michael-JAcger-2013US1020151124LRGB_1448402705.jpg http://spaceweathergallery.com/full_image.php?image_name=Michael-JAcger-2013US1020151124LRGB_1448402705.jpg

Regards
Michael Jäger 
Date:  Wed, 25 Nov 2015 09:51:49 +1100
From:  mmatti@westnet.com.au
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2013 US10 Nov.24 LRGB
Excellent image Michael!

If you look carefully. you can see 3 tails here.
The Type I ion tail in PA 286.
The very short and stubby Type II dust tail in PA 240 (dust particles released at perihelion)
and the impressive Type III dust “trail” in PA 163 (heavy particles released prior to perihelion)
The angle of separation between ion tail and dust trail will remain this way until after Earth approach, closing to 90 degrees in late January.

best regards,
Michael Mattiazzo

From: mailto:Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, November 25, 2015 9:08 AM
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [Comet-Images] C/2013 US10 Nov.24 LRGB

Comet low 5°

Nov 24 4.45 UT 8"/2.8 FLI 8300
L-2x120 UV/IR 1x120 green 1x120 blue 4x120 red
Weißenkirchen Austria

http://spaceweathergallery.com/full_image.php?image_name=Michael-JAcger-2013US1020151124LRGB_1448402705.jpg

Regards
Michael Jäger 
Date:  Tue, 24 Nov 2015 23:35:05 +0000
From:  John Nassr 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2013 US10 Nov.24 LRGB
Michael,
Excellent capture of a very interesting comet that many are wondering how it will appear in the coming weeks.
John

On Wednesday, November 25, 2015 6:52 AM, "mmatti@westnet.com.au [Comet-Images]" wrote:

  Excellent image Michael! If you look carefully. you can see 3 tails here.The Type I ion tail in PA 286.The very short and stubby Type II dust tail in PA 240 (dust particles released at perihelion)and the impressive Type III dust “trail” in PA 163 (heavy particles released prior to perihelion)The angle of separation between ion tail and dust trail will remain this way until after Earth approach, closing to 90 degrees in late January. best regards,Michael Mattiazzo  From: mailto:Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com Sent: Wednesday, November 25, 2015 9:08 AMTo: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com Subject: [Comet-Images] C/2013 US10 Nov.24 LRGB   Comet low 5°  Nov 24  4.45 UT 8"/2.8 FLI 8300L-2x120 UV/IR 1x120 green 1x120 blue 4x120 redWeißenkirchen Austria  http://spaceweathergallery.com/full_image.php?image_name=Michael-JAcger-2013US1020151124LRGB_1448402705.jpg
  RegardsMichael Jäger #yiv0001755417 #yiv0001755417 -- #yiv0001755417ygrp-mkp {border:1px solid #d8d8d8;font-family:Arial;margin:10px 0;padding:0 10px;}#yiv0001755417 #yiv0001755417ygrp-mkp hr Date:  Wed, 25 Nov 2015 00:59:38 +0100
From:  "José J. Chambó" 
Subject:  C/2013 US10 Catalina on Nov. 24
Object/Date:Comet C/2013 US10 (Catalina) @ November 24, 2015
Description:Comet C/2013 US10 (Catalina) imaged on November 24th 2015 peeks to the boreal skies, at only 5 degrees of altitude above southeast horizon during the morning twilight and shinning with 6th magnitude. Shows two tails both with 0.5 deg longitude, the dust tail toward southeast and the ionic tail toward west.
Location:Llosa de Ranes, Valencia (Spain) Tech data:GSO 8" @ f/3.8 reflector & Canon EOS-100D camera (16x30 sec. at ISO 1600)
Post and image link:http://cometografia.es/2013us10-catalina-20151124/

Regards.
José J. Chambó (Valencia, Spain)blog: cometografia.es twitter: @PepeChambo 

Date:  Wed, 25 Nov 2015 00:09:46 +0000
From:  John Nassr 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2013 US10 Catalina on Nov. 24
Jose,
A beauty! The DSLR captured it nicely.
John

Date:  Wed, 25 Nov 2015 16:50:13 +0000
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet 67P overview
Hi all,
I created a composite overview image showing 67P between September and November. Its been quite a nice looking comet in larger scopes. The tail seems to have become more fan shaped with time, though a narrow component to the tail has remained pretty constant the last few months.
http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/67p_sepnov_dp.jpg
All images LRGB with 24"CDK and FLI camera.
Best Wishes
Damian

*************************************************
Web: http://www.damianpeach.com/
FB: http://www.facebook.com/peachastro
Email: dpeach_78@yahoo.co.uk
*************************************************

https://www.flickr.com/photos/hiroc/23347060746/

C/2013 US10 Catalina in Virgo with FSQ-106ED Novembe... https://www.flickr.com/photos/hiroc/23347060746/ Two tails got visible clearly at the night. The altitude of the comet was around 8 degrees, and 16-day moon was in the east. Earth Distance: 1.601 AU Sun Dis...

Date:  Thu, 03 Dec 2015 03:25:40 +0000
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Comet Catalina US10 this morning from Payson
Hello All,

with the bright half moon lighting up the sky this morning, I did not expect to get much of a shot of this comet, however despite the noisy background - the tails were recorded fairly well.  Surprising details in the gas tail when I made the negative image, as you will see!

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/CatalinaUS10-120215.html

Visually in the 80mm with a Panoptic 35mm eyepiece yielding 15x, the comet was pretty dissapointing, but hey - its only 10 degrees up at the start of twilight.  Better things to come...

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com 

Date:  Thu, 03 Dec 2015 06:30:13 -0600
From:  Doug Durig 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Comet Catalina US10 this morning from Payson
The comet is getting a lot easier to image since it is rising earlier and 5
degrees more north in declination. There is a LOT of detail in the gas
tail. My FOV is only around 11x16 arc minutes so I don't get the full
length of the tail, but you can see multiple streamers in the gas/ion tail.

Here is my latest stack of 40x 30 sec images from 12/3 UT:

http://arthur.sewanee.edu/obsv/view_c.php

Doug

On Wed, Dec 2, 2015 at 9:25 PM, Chris Schur comets133@yahoo.com
[Comet-Images] wrote:

>
> Hello All,
>
> with the bright half moon lighting up the sky this morning, I did not
> expect to get much of a shot of this comet, however despite the noisy
> background - the tails were recorded fairly well. Surprising details in
> the gas tail when I made the negative image, as you will see!
>
> http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/CatalinaUS10-120215.html
>
> Visually in the 80mm with a Panoptic 35mm eyepiece yielding 15x, the comet
> was pretty dissapointing, but hey - its only 10 degrees up at the start of
> twilight. Better things to come...
>
> Clear Skies,
>
> Chris Schur
>
> Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com
>

Nils Vest
Date:  Fri, 04 Dec 2015 06:58:37 -0600
From:  Doug Durig 
Subject:  Comet Catalina animations 12/04/15
Now that Comet Catalina C/2013 US10 is rising earlier and at a higher
declination, a LOT of structure is starting to show up in the gas tail/s.
These animations show great details. The smaller FOV doesn't have as much
glare from near-field stars, but doesn't show as many kinks in the tail.
That is what is causing the strange static streaks in the 20x30 arc minutes
images. But with a ninth magnitude star just about an arc minutes off of
the edge of the frame, it almost looks like another comet tail running
opposite of the gas/ion tail. What is the correct term for the striations
in the gas tail... I thought it was isochrones but I can't find a proper
reference.

Animations are here:

http://arthur.sewanee.edu/obsv/view_c.php

Doug Durig
Cordell-Lorenz Observatory
Sewanee, Tennessee
Obs Code 850 
Date:  Fri, 04 Dec 2015 14:00:26 -0000

Date:  Fri, 04 Dec 2015 10:43:35 -0500
From:  Paul Mortfield 
Subject:  2013US10 Catalina - Dec 2
9x30sec using my 16f/8.9 in California. Taking in twilight. FOV ½ degree
wide. North is up.

http://www.backyardastronomer.com/comets/C2013US10_Catalina_20151202d.jpg

inverted to bring out more detail in the ion tail.

http://www.backyardastronomer.com/comets/C2013US10_Catalina_20151202d_inv.jp
g

thanks for looking.


paul.

Date:  Fri, 04 Dec 2015 20:09:47 -0000
From:  Peter Carson 
Subject:  C2013US10 from Essex UK
In the last day or two the comet has risen high enough in the dawn skies from the south of the UK to enable us comet observers to get at it.
See my image from this morning image taken from my light polluted home observatory. The tail structure is really detailed.
Next opportunity I will use my wider field refractor.
http://www.astromania.co.uk/2013US10_20151204_0604_PCarson.jpg
Peter Carson
Leigh on sea
Essex UK

Date:  Sun, 06 Dec 2015 01:22:34 +0100
From:  "José J. Chambó" 
Subject:  67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko on Nov.19
Object/Date:67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko @ Nov.19,2015
Description:Comet 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko imaged on November 19th 2015 with a brightness of 12.5 magnitude shows a tail at least 12 arcminutes longitude. The bright orange star is HD 99196 with magnitude 5.8 and next to it the spiral galaxy NGC 3666.
Tech data:Planewave 20" CDK & FLI PL11002M (L:2×120s bin1, RGB:1x60s bin2) cropped
Location:Remotely from Mayhill, New Mexico (USA)
Post and image link:http://cometografia.es/67p-churyumov-gerasimenko-20151119/

Regards.
José J. Chambó (Valencia, Spain)blog: cometografia.es twitter: @PepeChambo

Hello All,

One day before the Moon-Venus-comet conjunction, I thought Id get a deeper shot of the comet, now that the moon is still far away and a small crescent. Much more of the ion tail is showing up now:

Date:  Sun, 06 Dec 2015 15:16:24 -0800
From:  jbrimaco@bigpond.net.au
Subject:  Comet C/2013 U10 Catalina: three tails and a disconnection event - Dec 4, 2015
Taken from New Mexico Skies Observatory using an FSQ 106 telescope and STL-11000 camera on a PME II mount with AOL guiding. Shows all three tails and a disconnection event.
Time: 12h 21m UT; 1 x 20 min exposure.

LINKS
Positive image: https://www.flickr.com/photos/43846774@N02/22941650874/
Negative image: https://www.flickr.com/photos/43846774@N02/23543803306/

Clear, still skies
Joe

Joseph Brimacombe
Coral Towers Observatory

Cairns, Australia

Subject:  C/2013 US10 (Dec 5th)
Hi all,
Here is my first image of this comet since it emerged into the dawn skies. Its two distinct tails are nicely apparent. The ion tail shows several streamers.

Inviato da iPhone

> Il giorno 08/dic/2015, alle ore 08:56, "michaeljaeger@gmx.at [Comet-Images]" ha scritto:
>
> Hello
>
> LRGB from Dec 7 UT 4.45
>
> L-4x270sec 2x2 bin
>
> RGB 240/240/240 4x4
>
> 10"/4 Moravian G3-11002
>
> Regards
>
> Michael Jäger
>
> http://spaceweathergallery.com/full_image.php?image_name=Michael-JAcger-2014US1020151207lrgbjaeger_1449560511.jpg
> 
Date:  Tue, 08 Dec 2015 12:15:19 +0000
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2013 US10 Dec. 7 LRGB
Michael, a very strong anti tail for this comet on your image, I think as we approach orbital plane crossing the view will become out of this world. Nice colors!

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com

Date:  Wed, 09 Dec 2015 16:29:50 +0100
From:  Gerald Rhemann 
Subject:  2013US10 Dec 7
Hello everybody,

Originally I thought it is not worth to post this image, but finally I
invested several hours at processing to get out the best.

Here is one of the original unprocessed but calibrated Luminance files where
Venus and Moon defaced the image with reflection in every way:

s/312_2013US10_07_12_SW.jpg>
http://www.astrostudio.at/2_Bright%20Comets.php?img=images/2_Bright%20Comets
/312_2013US10_07_12_SW.jpg

Here is the final LRGB image after many hours of processing:

s/313_2013US10_07_12.jpg>
http://www.astrostudio.at/2_Bright%20Comets.php?img=images/2_Bright%20Comets
/313_2013US10_07_12.jpg

best regards

Gerald

From: "'Gerald Rhemann' gerald.rhemann@gmail.com [Comet-Images]"
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, 9 December 2015, 15:29
Subject: [Comet-Images] 2013US10 Dec 7

Hello everybody,

Originally I thought it is not worth to post this image, but finally I invested several hours at processing to get out the best.

Here is one of the original unprocessed but calibrated Luminance files where Venus and Moon defaced the image with reflection in every way:

http://www.astrostudio.at/2_Bright%20Comets.php?img=images/2_Bright%20Comets/312_2013US10_07_12_SW.jpg

Here is the final LRGB image after many hours of processing:

http://www.astrostudio.at/2_Bright%20Comets.php?img=images/2_Bright%20Comets/313_2013US10_07_12.jpg

best regards

Gerald

Date:  Wed, 09 Dec 2015 21:39:17 -0800
From:  jbrimaco@bigpond.net.au
Subject:  Comet C/2013 US10 Catalina Widefield L - Dec 8, 2015
Taken from New Mexico Skies Observatory using an FSQ 106 telescope and STL-11000 camera on a PME II mount with AOL guiding.
Time: 11h 50m UT; 1 x 30 min exposure.

LINKS
Positive image: https://www.flickr.com/photos/43846774@N02/23619643026/
Negative image: https://www.flickr.com/photos/43846774@N02/23277774059/

Clear, still skies
Joe

Joseph Brimacombe
Coral Towers Observatory

Cairns, Australia

From: "'Gerald Rhemann' gerald.rhemann@gmail.com [Comet-Images]"
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, 9 December 2015, 15:29
Subject: [Comet-Images] 2013US10 Dec 7

Hello everybody,

Originally I thought it is not worth to post this image, but finally I invested several hours at processing to get out the best.

Here is one of the original unprocessed but calibrated Luminance files where Venus and Moon defaced the image with reflection in every way:

http://www.astrostudio.at/2_Bright%20Comets.php?img=images/2_Bright%20Comets/312_2013US10_07_12_SW.jpg

Here is the final LRGB image after many hours of processing:

http://www.astrostudio.at/2_Bright%20Comets.php?img=images/2_Bright%20Comets/313_2013US10_07_12.jpg

best regards

Gerald

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com

the clouds went away
Dec 10  UT 4.43  3x270sec UV/IR
1x450blue10"/4 Moravian G3-11002

Gerald

On Wed, 12/9/15, 'Gerald Rhemann' gerald.rhemann@gmail.com [Comet-Images] wrote:

Subject: [Comet-Images] 2013US10 Dec 7
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wednesday, December 9, 2015, 8:29 AM

Hello everybody, Originally
I thought it is not worth to post this image, but finally I
invested several hours at processing to get out the best.
Here is
one of the original unprocessed but calibrated Luminance
files where Venus and Moon defaced the image with reflection
in every way:
http://www.astrostudio.at/2_Bright%20Comets.php?img=images/2_Bright%20Comets/312_2013US10_07_12_SW.jpg
Here is the final LRGB image after many hours
of processing:
http://www.astrostudio.at/2_Bright%20Comets.php?img=images/2_Bright%20Comets/313_2013US10_07_12.jpg
best
regards Gerald 

Date:  Thu, 10 Dec 2015 16:00:59 -0000
From:  Peter Carson 
Subject:  Recent images for the archive
Hi Denis,
There’ve been a few clear slots down here. Attached are 7 the images taken over three sessions.
I decided to swap to my wider field 100mm refractor for the 2013US10 image. Although is recorded a lot of detail it was a pig to remove all the light pollution gradients from a larger field of view. I guess you don’t have that problem...
All the best
Peter

Date:  Thu, 10 Dec 2015 16:45:41 -0600
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2013 US10 (Dec 8th)
If you remember there was only one individual who was predicting the "disintegration" of c/2013 US10; as with many other similar predictions from the same fellow, we now see that it was pretty much baseless.
We have an outstanding comet; your last photograph was simply incredible, Damian.

------------
Dr. Clay

Arkansas Sky Observatories
http://www.arksky.org/
ASO Petit Jean Mountain /MPC H41
ASO Petit Jean Mountain South /MPC H45
ASO West Conway /MPC H43
.......serving astronomy since 1971

Date:  Sun, 13 Dec 2015 08:38:55 -0800
From:  michaeljaeger@gmx.at
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 2013US10 Dec 11 LRGB
Hi Chris

To get a real deep comet image, it needs following requirements.

x a possible dark, transparent sky, if possible from higher altitudes
x longest possible exposure time in single shots, longer than two minutes
x mono CCD, working in binning mode
x to capture the ion tail, a blue-sensitive CCD is better
x If the comet is from Earth farther away you need focal lengths at 500-1000 at f-2.0-5.0

image processing
x combine at least 3 to 4 files
x if the comet moves quickly, you had to remove all stars from the images

Regards
Michael Jäger 

Date:  Sun, 13 Dec 2015 19:48:18 +0100

Date:  Mon, 14 Dec 2015 12:36:22 +0000
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 2013US10 Dec 11 LRGB
Michael,

Looks like I have the setup here, barring a better imaging scope. We have 7000 feet elevation with zero sky glow, my ST10xme is plenty blue sensitive, and I plan on getting a 10" f/3.9 astrograph as soon as the holiday rush is over. ;)

I would however in the mean time like to compare a blue filtered shot with one taken with my 48mm Lumicon swan band filter.

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com

Hi Chris
To get a real deep comet image,
it needs following requirements.
x a possible dark, transparent sky,
if possible from higher altitudesx longest
possible exposure time in single shots, longer than two
minutesx mono CCD, working in binning
modex  to capture the ion tail, a blue-sensitive
CCD is betterx If the
comet is from Earth farther away you need focal lengths at
500-1000 at f-2.0-5.0
image processingx combine
at least 3 to 4 filesx if the comet moves
quickly, you had to remove all stars from the
images
RegardsMichael
Jäger

Date:  Mon, 14 Dec 2015 23:35:10 -0800
From:  jbrimaco@bigpond.net.au
Subject:  Comet C/2013 U10 Catalina Widefield L - Dec 14, 2015
Taken from New Mexico Skies Observatory using an FSQ 106 telescope and STL-11000 camera on a PME II mount with AOL guiding. Time: 12h 12m UT; 1 x 30 min exposure.

LINKS
Positive image: https://www.flickr.com/photos/43846774@N02/23466168220/
Negative image: https://www.flickr.com/photos/43846774@N02/23135053753/
Clear, still skies
Joe

Joseph Brimacombe
Coral Towers Observatory
Cairns, Australia

Date:  Tue, 15 Dec 2015 05:01:09 -0800
From:  g22@poczta.onet.pl
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2013 US10 (Catalina) - 13 Dec. 2015
Chris,

That additional object is definitely a satellite. It is too short (and probably too symetric) to be a Geminid.

Best Regards
Piotr Guzik
Date:  Tue, 15 Dec 2015 10:26:59 -0800
From:  kodama@alumni.caltech.edu
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2013 US10 (Catalina) - 13 Dec. 2015
Chris,

Thanks! And thanks also to you and all the other comet shooters who crank out so many great shots so often. It is an important factor in motivating me to go out myself.

The other object was probably a satellite "flare". I was also shooting wide field photos hoping to catch some Geminids on that evening too, but I didn't catch many. Unfortunately, we had rain on the following evening when the peak was supposed to occur.

Dave

Date:  Wed, 16 Dec 2015 15:17:05 -0600
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2013 US10 (Dec 9th)
Michael....
Please contact me off group; you should not even consider leaving this group.
I frankly do not know what is going on with all the "atta-boys" directed toward some and the negativity toward others.

I look forward to talking with you; some excellent comet observers/imagers have already left this group (and comets.ml) because of unnecessary or excessive comments.

Thanks for all that you have done. Your work is by far the best and most serious in the business. Everyone's contributions are welcome and encouraged I would think.

------------
Dr. Clay

Arkansas Sky Observatories
http://www.arksky.org/
ASO Petit Jean Mountain /MPC H41
ASO Petit Jean Mountain South /MPC H45
ASO West Conway /MPC H43
.......serving astronomy since 1971

Date:  Wed, 16 Dec 2015 15:19:01 -0600
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2013 US10 (Dec 9th)
Frankly there should be no doubt that everyone's images of this comet that have been
posted thus far on this forum have been "realistic" and not "overdone."
Every image presented should and does present a varying degree of scientific
information. To imply that others do not, is simply not accurate.

Date:  Wed, 16 Dec 2015 14:35:03 -0800
From:  mfortsm@aol.com
Subject:  Hold The Phone Here.
I don't know what is going on here but intend to find out. I have been inactive for a while because of a couple of personal images but I don't like the way this is going. Michael you are the best or one of the top comet imagers in the world and hope you will let me find out whats going on before you push that quit button.
Mike Holloway 
Date:  Thu, 17 Dec 2015 00:01:26 +0100
From:  Gerald Rhemann 
Subject:  2013 US 10 Dec 16
Hello everybody,

We are clouded here in Austria. Thus I decided to take an image remotely at
the observatory in Namibia. I know the comet is at very low altitude there.
Anyway I tried it  starting at 4° altitude end up at 11° with a very short
time frame of 35 minutes. FOV is small  thus I made a two frame mosaic:

http://www.astrostudio.at/2_Bright%20Comets.php?img=images/2_Bright%20Comets
/317_2013US10_16_12.jpg

best regards

Gerald 

Date:  Wed, 16 Dec 2015 17:10:39 -0600
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 2013 US 10 Dec 16
Gerald....that is quite a field of view; what is the total coverage of the 12" ASA scope that you are using?
Very impressive for such a large telescope.

------------
Dr. Clay

Arkansas Sky Observatories
http://www.arksky.org/
ASO Petit Jean Mountain /MPC H41
ASO Petit Jean Mountain South /MPC H45
ASO West Conway /MPC H43
.......serving astronomy since 1971
____________________
----- Original Message -----
From: 'Gerald Rhemann' gerald.rhemann@gmail.com [Comet-Images]
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, December 16, 2015 5:01 PM
Subject: [Comet-Images] 2013 US 10 Dec 16

Hello everybody,

We are clouded here in Austria. Thus I decided to take an image remotely at the observatory in Namibia. I know the comet is at very low altitude there. Anyway I tried it - starting at 4° altitude end up at 11° with a very short time frame of 35 minutes. FOV is small - thus I made a two frame mosaic:

http://www.astrostudio.at/2_Bright%20Comets.php?img=images/2_Bright%20Comets/317_2013US10_16_12.jpg

best regards

Gerald

From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: Hold The Phone Here.
Thanks to both....
There is no reason for there to be hostility on this group, or through private messaging as I have been told there was.
We are all here to share a common interest....this is not competition and never should be.
When you start looking for quantity of postings or intentional disrespect for another observer/contributor, it is time to find another hobby.

Much appreciated Dave and Mike.

Dr. Clay

----- Original Message -----

From: 'Gerald Rhemann' gerald.rhemann@gmail.com [Comet-Images]


To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com

Sent: Wednesday, December 16, 2015 5:01 PM

Subject: [Comet-Images] 2013 US 10 Dec 16

Hello everybody,

We are clouded here in Austria. Thus I decided to take an image remotely at
the observatory in Namibia. I know the comet is at very low altitude there.
Anyway I tried it  starting at 4° altitude end up at 11° with a very short
time frame of 35 minutes. FOV is small  thus I made a two frame mosaic:

http://www.astrostudio.at/2_Bright%20Comets.php?img=images/2_Bright%20Comets
/317_2013US10_16_12.jpg

best regards

Gerald

Date:  Thu, 17 Dec 2015 05:35:01 -0800
From:  michaeljaeger@gmx.at
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2013 US10 (Dec 9th)
Damian

I support all the results shown here.
Here's behind a lot of work, personal money, passion.
What does not fit here, is a referee function.
Overdone is no word for a comet page.
I'm not going to justify my results here.
And it's also not a good way, how to talk about results.

Regards
MJ 
Date:  Thu, 17 Dec 2015 14:06:15 +0000
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 2013 US 10 Dec 16
Oh Gerald, stop downplaying your image - its a killer shot. My mount froze up solid yesterday when I tried to image the comet, it was 11F out and I have to set up in a snow bank. Time to get out that electric blanket for the mount..

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Hello
everybody,  We are
clouded here in Austria. Thus I decided to take an image
remotely at the observatory in Namibia. I know the comet is
at very low altitude there. Anyway I tried it –
starting at 4° altitude end up at 11° with a very short
time frame of 35 minutes. FOV is small – thus I made a
two frame mosaic:

Date:  Sat, 19 Dec 2015 03:23:29 +0000
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Comet Catalina US10 - Gas tail very dim this morning on 12/18.
Hello all,

Our final round of balcony comet shooting with the Stellarvue SV80 looking over the pine tree tops from our home in northern Arizona.  The next time will be in the backyard observatory with the 12.5 inch since it is finally high enough to clear the trees by 5am.

A bit disappointed in the ion tail here, it was so much stronger  last week. The dust / Anti-tail is still very strong however!  Now how cool is that?!  Thanks for looking.

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/CatalinaUS10-1201815.html

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com

Martin, well you got me beat this morning - I set up and started 1 min subs for a long set and after only 1 minute the sky went from mag 7 visual to mag 1 and blanked out with super thick haze! Never seen it happen that fast before....

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Yahoo Groups Links

Date:  Sat, 19 Dec 2015 20:02:30 +0100
From:  "José J. Chambó" 
Subject:  C/2013 US10 Catalina (Dec.14,2015)
Object/Date:C/2013 US10 (Catalina) @ Dec.14,2015
Description:Comet C/2013 US10 (Catalina) imaged on December 14th 2015. Once has reached enough altitude in the sky at dawn in Northern Hemisphere, with a brightness of 6.5 magnitude the comet shows a spectacular display of tails: a narrow and long ionic tail of bluish tone with several degrees of longitude that leaves the field towards West (upwards), other most brilliant and short dust tail of white-yellow tone formed by heavy dust particles that remain as a trail in the orbit of comet towards southeast (to right-bottom) and finally, located between both, one tail more faint and wide with fan shaped and more whitish formed by fine dust grains released after the comet perihelion. The redish star below the comet es Upsilon Virginis with 5.1 magnitude and the more visible galaxy at top beside tail is NGC 5496.
Tech data:Takahashi FSQ ED 106mm. f/5.0 & SBIG STL-1100M (L:3×300s Bin2 + RG:1x60s Bin4 + B:1x120s Bin4)
Location:Remotely from Mayhill, New Mexico (USA)
Post and image link:http://cometografia.es/2013us10-catalina-20151214/
Regards.
José J. Chambó (Valencia, Spain)blog: cometografia.es twitter: @PepeChambo 

Date:  Sat, 19 Dec 2015 22:24:35 +0000
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2013 US10 Catalina (Dec.14,2015)
Jose, I like the image and even more the diagram showing the comets orbit. What software was that used for this?

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com

On Sat, 12/19/15, José J. Chambó jjchambo@hotmail.com [Comet-Images] wrote:

Subject: [Comet-Images] C/2013 US10 Catalina (Dec.14,2015)
To: "Comet images"
Date: Saturday, December 19, 2015, 12:02 PM

Object/Date:C/2013 US10
(Catalina) @ Dec.14,2015
Description:Comet
C/2013 US10 (Catalina) imaged on December 14th 2015. Once
has reached enough altitude in the sky at dawn in Northern
Hemisphere, with a brightness of 6.5 magnitude the comet
shows a spectacular display of tails: a narrow and long
ionic tail of bluish tone with several degrees of longitude
that leaves the field towards West (upwards), other most
brilliant and short dust tail of white-yellow tone formed by
heavy dust particles that remain as a trail in the orbit of
comet towards southeast (to right-bottom) and finally,
located between both, one tail more faint and wide with fan
shaped and more whitish formed by fine dust grains released
after the comet perihelion. The redish star below the comet
es Upsilon Virginis with 5.1 magnitude and the more visible
galaxy at top beside tail is NGC 5496.
Tech data:Takahashi FSQ ED 106mm. f/5.0 & SBIG STL-1100M
(L:3×300s Bin2 + RG:1x60s Bin4 + B:1x120s Bin4)
Location:Remotely
from Mayhill, New Mexico (USA)
Post and image link:http://cometografia.es/2013us10-catalina-20151214/
Regards.
José
J. Chambó (Valencia,
Spain)blog: cometografia.es
twitter: @PepeChambo 

Date:  Sun, 20 Dec 2015 12:35:52 +0100
From:  "José J. Chambó" 
Subject:  RE: [Comet-Images] C/2013 US10 Catalina (Dec.14,2015)
Hi Chris.
This diagram was done by Rob Kaufman, orbits traced using OrbitViewer JAVA applet, on wich Rob draw the tails manually :http://www.astroarts.com/products/orbitviewer/
This applet is available online in some sites, for instance here:http://neo.jpl.nasa.gov/orbits/
Nowadays don't works on Chrome, but for instance works on Firefox.
He published the original diagram here:https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=914599098617332&set=p.914599098617332&type=3&permPage=1

Regards.
José J. Chambó (Valencia, Spain)blog: cometografia.es twitter: @PepeChambo

To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com

On Sat, 12/19/15, José J. Chambó jjchambo@hotmail.com [Comet-Images] wrote:

Subject: [Comet-Images] C/2013 US10 Catalina (Dec.14,2015)

To: "Comet images"

Date: Saturday, December 19, 2015, 12:02 PM

Object/Date:C/2013 US10

(Catalina) @ Dec.14,2015

Description:Comet

C/2013 US10 (Catalina) imaged on December 14th 2015. Once

has reached enough altitude in the sky at dawn in Northern

Hemisphere, with a brightness of 6.5 magnitude the comet

shows a spectacular display of tails: a narrow and long

ionic tail of bluish tone with several degrees of longitude

that leaves the field towards West (upwards), other most

brilliant and short dust tail of white-yellow tone formed by

heavy dust particles that remain as a trail in the orbit of

comet towards southeast (to right-bottom) and finally,

located between both, one tail more faint and wide with fan

shaped and more whitish formed by fine dust grains released

after the comet perihelion. The redish star below the comet

es Upsilon Virginis with 5.1 magnitude and the more visible

galaxy at top beside tail is NGC 5496.

Tech data:Takahashi FSQ ED 106mm. f/5.0 & SBIG STL-1100M

(L:3×300s Bin2 + RG:1x60s Bin4 + B:1x120s Bin4)

Location:Remotely

from Mayhill, New Mexico (USA)

Post and image link:http://cometografia.es/2013us10-catalina-20151214/

Regards.

José

J. Chambó (Valencia,

Spain)blog: cometografia.es

Date:  Tue, 29 Dec 2015 12:58:59 +0100
From:  "José J. Chambó" 
Subject:  C/2013 US10 Catalina (Dec.21,2015)
Object/Date:C/2013 US10 (Catalina) @ Dec.21,2015
Description:Comet C/2013 US10 (Catalina) imaged on December 21th 2015, latest image of this comet on this year without moonlight. A mosaic of nearly 5 degrees width and 3 degrees height in which are highlighted some details of the long and bluish ionic tail as rays in the initial part, knots along its axis, and a important disconnection at the end. The brighter trail that leaves the yellowish and short dust tail departs toward southeast, unfolding it with fan shape more faint in a wide angle until the ionic tail. At left of the greenish coma there are an interesting group of galaxies being NGC 5566 the biggest.
Tech data:Takahashi FSQ ED 106mm. f/5.0 & SBIG STL-1100M 2x(L:2×240s + RGB:1x60s Bin2)
Location:Remotely from Mayhill, New Mexico (USA)
Post and image link:http://cometografia.es/2013us10-catalina-20151221/
Regards.
José J. Chambó (Valencia, Spain)blog: cometografia.es twitter: @PepeChambo

Date:  Wed, 30 Dec 2015 18:44:30 +0000
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Comet Catalina US10 this morning from Payson
Hello all,

finally a clear morning without the horrific wind that has plagued the western US this week. Just over half a moon, yet the comets gas tail was quite evident this morning. Visually, the comet had no appendages, however it was easy in the binoculars!

Image:

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/CatalinaUS10-123015.html

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com 

Date:  Wed, 30 Dec 2015 20:20:58 +0000

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Date:  Thu, 31 Dec 2015 11:02:06 +0100
From:  Erik Bryssinck 
Subject:  comet C/2013 US10 on 31 dec.2015
130th observation of comet C/2013 US10 (CATALINA)

http://www.astronomie.be/erik.bryssinck/c2013us10_20151231.html

kind regards,

Erik Bryssinck & Franz-Josef Hambsch

BRIXIIS Observatory (MPC:B96)

ROAD Observatory (G39)

http://www.astronomie.be/erik.bryssinck/

Date:  Thu, 31 Dec 2015 04:07:09 -0800
From:  martin.gembec@gmail.com
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Three PanSTARRS comets from the UK
Mike

I'm happy to see some images instead of none. Thanks to your activity one can see how are comets behaving, because you are using the same technics.

Las night I tried to image three PanSTARRSes too.

Here I have images

2014 S2 20151230 around 17:45UT 9×60 s, ISO 1600, Celestron ED80/600 + Vixen 0,67× (f5/402 mm), Canon 30Dmod, cropped and resized to 50 %
http://udalosti.astronomy.cz/wp-content/2014s2-20151230.jpg http://udalosti.astronomy.cz/wp-content/2014s2-20151230.jpg

http://udalosti.astronomy.cz/wp-content/2014s2-20151230.jpg

http://udalosti.astronomy.cz/wp-content/2014s2-20151230.... http://udalosti.astronomy.cz/wp-content/2014s2-20151230.jpg

View on udalosti.astronomy.cz http://udalosti.astronomy.cz/wp-content/2014s2-20151230.jpg
Preview by Yahoo

2014 W2 20151230 around 18:15UT 13×60 s, ISO 1600, Celestron ED80/600 + Vixen 0,67× (f5/402 mm), Canon 30Dmod, 100 %, cropped
http://udalosti.astronomy.cz/wp-content/2014w2-201512301.jpg http://udalosti.astronomy.cz/wp-content/2014w2-201512301.jpg

http://udalosti.astronomy.cz/wp-content/2014w2-201512301.jpg

http://udalosti.astronomy.cz/wp-content/2014w2-201512301... http://udalosti.astronomy.cz/wp-content/2014w2-201512301.jpg

View on udalosti.astronomy.cz http://udalosti.astronomy.cz/wp-content/2014w2-201512301.jpg
Preview by Yahoo

2014 X1 20151230 around 18:45 UT 7×60 s, ISO 1600, Celestron ED80/600 + Vixen 0,67× (f5/402 mm), Canon 30Dmod, 100 %, cropped
http://udalosti.astronomy.cz/wp-content/2014x1-20151230.jpg http://udalosti.astronomy.cz/wp-content/2014x1-20151230.jpg

http://udalosti.astronomy.cz/wp-content/2014x1-20151230.jpg

http://udalosti.astronomy.cz/wp-content/2014x1-20151230.... http://udalosti.astronomy.cz/wp-content/2014x1-20151230.jpg

View on udalosti.astronomy.cz http://udalosti.astronomy.cz/wp-content/2014x1-20151230.jpg
Preview by Yahoo

If you can see our starparty report and image of M 31, you can go (in czech)
Astronomické události » Blog Archive » Lov komet a deep-sky na Kopanině http://udalosti.astronomy.cz/?p=6296

Astronomické události » Blog Archive » Lov komet a deep-sky na Kopanině http://udalosti.astronomy.cz/?p=6296 Ani krutá zima, ani uragán nás nezastaví. Ani jedno naštěstí nedorazilo, ale nebylo k tomu daleko.

View on udalosti.astronomy.cz http://udalosti.astronomy.cz/?p=6296
Preview by Yahoo

Happy new comet year 2016

Martin Gembec 

Date:  Thu, 31 Dec 2015 14:59:13 +0100
From:  Alfons Diepvens 
Subject:  C23 -NEW images 29-30 Dec 2015


NEW images 29-30 Dec 2015

44P Reinmuth
67P Churyumov-Gerasimenko
81P Wild
162P Siding-Spring
204P LINEAR-NEAT
230P LINEAR
329P LINEAR-Catalina

C2013 US10 Catalina
C2013 US10 Catalina - false color
C2013 X1 Panstarrs

C2014 S2 Panstarrs
C2014 S2 Panstarrs - nucleus
C2014 S2 Panstarrs - false color

C2010 U3 Boattini
C2013 V4 Catalina
C2015 V2 Johnson
C2015 X4 ELENIN
C2015 X8 NEOWISE

2008 CM - fly by asteroid

with a direct link to the image:
http://www.astronomie.be/alfons.diepvens/cometimages/index.html

Alfons Diepvens 
Date:  Thu, 31 Dec 2015 14:40:35 +0000

Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Three PanSTARRS comets from the UK

Following Martins post of 3 comets from UK skies, I attach images of 5 comets taken from my UK skies in Highland Scotland

last night (20151230).Best wishes for 2016 to all on this list.Denis BuczynskiSecretary Comet SectionBritish Astronomical Association

From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Catalina US10 - 123115 - With 12.5" this morning
